He (the narrator) said: Abu Bakr and Bilal were there with him among those who had embraced Islam by that time. I said: I intend to follow you. He said: During these days you would not be able to do so. Don't you see the (hard) condition under which I and (my) people are living? You better go back to your people and when you hear that I have been granted victory, you come to me. So I went to my family. I was in my home when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came to Medina. I was among my people and used to seek news and ask people when he arrived in Medina. Then a group of people belonging to Yathrib (Medina) came. I said (to them): How is that person getting on who has come to Medina? They said: The people are hastening to him, while his people (the polytheists of Mecca) planned to kill him, but they could not do so. I (on hearing it) came to Medina and went to him and said: Messenger of Allah, do you recognise me? He said: Yes, you are the same man who met me at Mecca. I said: It is so. I again said: Prophet of Allah, tell me that which Allah has taught you and which I do not know, tell me about the prayer. 
He said: Observe the dawn prayer, then stop praying when the sun is rising till it is fully up, for when it rises it comes up between the horns of Satan, and the unbelievers prostrate themselves to it at that time. Then pray, for the prayer is witnessed and attended (by angels) till the shadow becomes about the length of a lance; then cease prayer, for at that time Hell is heated up. Then when the shadow moves forward, pray, for the prayer is witnessed and attended by angels, till you pray the afternoon prayer, then cease prayer till the sun sets, for it sets between the horns of devil, and at that time the unbelievers prostrate themselves before it. I said: Apostle of Allah, tell me about ablution also. He said: None of you who uses water for ablution and rinses his mouth, snuffs up water and blows it, but the sins of his face, and his mouth and his nostrils fall out. When he washes his face, as Allah has commanded him, the sins of his face fall out from the end of his beard with water. Then (when) he washes his forearms up to the elbows, the sins of his arms fall out along with water from his finger-tips. And when he wipes his head, the sins of his head fall out from the points of his hair along with water. And (when) he washes his feet up to the ankles, the sins of his feet fall out from his toes along with water. And if he stands to pray and praises Allah, lauds Him and glorifies Him with what becomes Him and shows wholehearted devotion to Allah, his sins would depart leaving him (as innocent) as he was on the day his mother bore him. 'Amr b. 'Abasa narrated this hadith to Abu Umama, a Companion of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), and Abu Umama said to him: 'Amr b. 'Abasa, think what you are saying that such (a great reward) is given to a man at one place (only in the act of ablution and prayer). Upon this 'Amr said: Abu Umama, I have grown old and my bones have become weak and I am at the door of death; what impetus is there for me to attribute a lie to Allah and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)? Had I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) once, twice, or three times (even seven times), I would have never narrated it, but I have heard it from him on occasions more than these.
question: What were the key teachings that the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) was sent with according to this narration?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that 'Umar misconstrued the fact that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had prohibited the observance of prayer at the time of the rising sun and at the time of its setting.
question: What are the specific times during which prayer is prohibited in Islam?

hadith-eng: Do not get used to observe prayer at the time of the rising sun and at the time of its setting and (exhorted the Muslims) to pray at their times.
question: What are the recommended times for performing prayers according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I along with 'Umar b. al-Khattab dissuaded people to do so (to observe two rak'ahs of prayer). Kuraib said: I went to her ('A'isha) and conveyed to her the message with which I was sent. She said: (Better) ask Umm Salama. So I went to them (those who had sent him to Hadrat 'A'isha) and informed them about what she had said. They sent me back to Umm Salama with that with which I was sent to 'A'isha. Umm Salama said: I beard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prohibiting them, and then afterwards I saw him observing them. And when he observed them (two rak'ahs) he had already observed the 'Asr prayer. Then he (the Holy Prophet) came, while there were with me ladies of Banu Haram, a tribe of the Ansar and he (the Holy Prophet) observed them (the two rak'ahs). I sent a slave-girl to him asking her to stand by his side and say to him that Umm Salama says: Messenger of Allah, I heard you prohibiting these two rak'ahs, whereas I saw you observing them; and if he (the Holy Prophet) points with his hand (to wait), then do wait. The slave-girl did like that. He (the Holy Prophet) pointed out with his hand and she got aside and waited, and when he had finished (the prayer) he said: Daughter of Abu Umayya. you have asked about the two rak'ahs after the 'Asr prayer. Some people of 'Abu al-Qais came to me for embracing Islam and hindered me from observing the two rak'ahs which come after the noon prayer. So those are the two I have been praying.
question: What is the significance of observing additional rak'ahs after the 'Asr prayer in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: He (the Holy Prophet) observed them before the 'Asr prayer, but then he was hindered to do so, or he forgot them and then he observed them after the 'Asr, and then he continued observing them. (It was his habit) that when he (the Holy Prophet) observed prayer, he then continued observing it. Isma'il said: It implies that he always did that.
question: What is the significance of consistency in performing voluntary prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not abandon at all observing two rak'ahs after the 'Asr in my house.
question: What is the significance of performing two rak'ahs after the 'Asr prayer in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: Two are the prayers which the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) always observed in my house-openly or secretly-two rak'ahs before the dawn and two rak'ahs after the 'Asr.
question: What are the specific times during the day when additional prayers are recommended?

hadith-eng: We bear testimony to the fact that 'A'isha said: Never was there a day that he (the Holy Prophet) was with me and he did not observe two rak'ahs of prayer in my house, i. e. two rak'ahs after the Asr.
question: What is the significance of performing additional prayers after the Asr prayer?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas b. Malik about the voluntary prayers after the afternoon prayer, and he replied: 'Umar struck hit hands on prayer observed after the 'Asr prayer and we used to observe two rak'ahs after the sun set before the evening prayer during the time of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). I said to him: Did the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observe them? He said: He saw us observing them, but he neither commanded us nor forbade us to do so.
question: What is the significance of voluntary prayers after the 'Asr prayer in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: When we were in Medina, the moment the Mu'adhdhin made the call to the sunset prayer, the people hastened to the pillars of the mosque and prayed two rak'ahs with the result that any stranger coming into the mosque would think that the obligatory prayer had been observed owing to the number who were praying then.
question: What is the significance of praying two rak'ahs before the obligatory sunset prayer in the mosque?

hadith-eng: There Is between the two calls (Adhan and Iqama) a prayer. And he mentioned it three times, and at the third time he said: This applies to those who wish to do it.
question: What is the significance of offering a prayer between the Adhan and Iqama?

hadith-eng: " He who wishes (may do to)."
question: What is the significance of offering additional voluntary prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) led on* of the two groups In one rak'ah of prayer in danger, while the other group faced the -enemy. Then they (the members of the first group) went back and replaced their companions who were facing the enemy. and then they (the members of the second group) came and the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) led them in one rak'ah of prayer. Then the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) pronounced salutation, and then they (the members of the Ant group) completed the rak'ah and they (the members of the second group) completed the rak'ah.
question: How is the prayer conducted during times of danger or battle according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been narrated by another chain of transmitters.
question: What is the significance of multiple chains of transmission in the authentication of hadiths?

hadith-eng: a group stood with him (the Holy Prophet) (for prayer) and the other group stood In front of the enemy. Then those who were with (him) observed one rak'ah of prayer and they went back and the others came and they observed one rak'ah (with him). Then both the groups completed one rak'ah each. Ibn Umar said: When there is greater danger, then observe prayer even on the ride or with the help of gestures in a standing posture.
question: How can Muslims perform prayers during times of danger or conflict?

hadith-eng: I observed prayer in danger with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). We drew ourselves up in two rows, one row behind him with the enemy between us and the Qibla. The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said: Allah is Most Great, and we all said it. He then bowed and we all bowed. He then raised his head from bowing, we all raised (our heads). He then went down in prostration along with the row close to him, and the rear row faced the enemy; then when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) completed the prostration, ; and then stood up, the row near to him also did it; then went down the rear row in prostration; then they stood up; then the rear row went to the front and the front row went to the rear. Then the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) bowed down and we all bowed. He then raised his head from bowing and we also raised (our heads). He and the row close to him which I had been in the rear then went down in prostration In the first rak'ah, whereas the rear row faced the enemy. And when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and the rear row close to him had finished the prostration, the rear row went down and prostrated themselves; then the Messenger of Allah pronounced the salutation and we also pronounced the salutation. (Jabir said we hadith) as your guards behave with their chiefs.
question: How is the prayer conducted in a situation of danger according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: We fought In the company of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) with the tribe of Juhaina. They fought with us terribly. When we had finished the noon prayer, the polytheists said: Had we attacked them at once. we would have killed them. Gabriel informed the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about It (about their evil design). The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) made a mention of it to us, adding that they (the polytheists) had also said: Shortly there would be time for the 'Asr prayer. which is dearer o them (the Muslims) than even their children. So when the time of the 'Asr prayer came. we formed ourselves into two rows, while the polytheists were between us and the Qibla. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Allah is Most Great, and we also said so. He bowed and we also bowed. He went down in prostration and the first row prostrated along with him. When they stood up, the second row went down in prostration. Then the first row went into the rear, and the second row came in the front and occupied the place of the first row. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) then said: Allah is Most Great, and we also said so. He then bowed, and we also bowed. He then went down in prostration and along with him the row also (went down in prostration), and the second row remained standing. And when the second row had also prostrated and all of them sat down then the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) pronounced salutation to them. Abu Zubair said: Jabir made a mention specially of this thing: just as your chiefs observe prayer.
question: How did the Muslims adapt their prayer routine during a time of conflict to ensure their safety?

hadith-eng: Sahl b. Abu Hathma reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) led his Companions in prayer in danger. He made them stand in two rows behind him. He led them who were close to him in one rak'ah. He then stood up and kept standing till those who were behind them observed one rak'ah. Then they (those standing in the second row) came in front and those who were in front went into the rear. He then led them In one rak'ah. He then sat down, till those who were behind him observed one rak'ah and then pronounced salutation.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) conduct the prayer in a situation of danger?

hadith-eng: Yazid b. Ruman told on the authority of Salih b. Khawwat on the authority of one who prayed in time of danger with Allah's Messenger (may peace he upon him) at the Battle of Dhat ar-Riqa' that a group formed a row and prayed along with him, and a group faced the enemy. He led the group which was along with him in a rak'ah, then remained standing while they finished the prayer by themselves. Then they departed and formed a row facing the enemy. Then the second group came and he led them in the remaining rak'ah, after which he remained seated while they finished the prayer themselves. He then led them in salutation.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) manage the prayer during times of danger or battle?

hadith-eng: We went forward with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and when we reached Dhat ar-Riqa', we came to a shady tree which -we left for him One of the polytheists came there and, seeing the sword of the Messenger (ﷺ) hanging by a free. took it up. drew it from the scabbard and said to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ): Are you afraid of Me? He (the Holy Prophet) said: No. He again said: Who would protect you from me? He said: Allah will protect me from you. The Companions of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) threatened him. He sheathed the sword and hung it up. Then call to prayer was made and he (the Holy Prophet) led a group in two rak'ah. Then (the members of this group) withdrew and he led the second group in two rak'ah. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed four rak'ah and people observed two rak'ah.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate his trust in Allah when faced with danger?

hadith-eng: Abu Salama b. 'Abd al-Rahman reported that Jabir told him that he had observed the prayer in danger with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) (first) led one of the two groups in two rak'ah of prayer. and then led the second group in two rak'ah of prayer. So the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed four rak'ah and led in two rak'ah each of the groups.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) conduct the prayer in a situation of danger?

hadith-eng: The prayer was prescribed as two rak'ahs, two rak'ahs both in journey and at the place of residence. The prayer while travelling remained as it was (originally prescribed), but an addition was made in the prayer (observed) at the place of residence.
question: What was the original prescription for the number of rak'ahs in prayer during travel and residence?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), said Allah prescribed the prayer as two rak'ahs, then it was completed (to four rak'ahs) at the place of residence, but was retained in the same position in journey as it was first made obligatory.
question: What is the significance of maintaining the original number of rak'ahs for travelers in Islam?

hadith-eng: The prayer was prescribed as consisting of two rak'ahs, the prayer in travelling remained the same, but the prayer at the place of residence was completed. (Zuhri said he asked 'Urwa why 'A'isha said prayer in the complete form during journey, and he replied that she interpreted the matter herself as 'Uthman did.)
question: What was 'A'isha's interpretation regarding the prayer during travel?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. He replied: I wondered about it in the same way as you wonder about it, so I asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about it and he said: It is an act of charity which Allah has done to you, so accept His charity.
question: How does the concept of divine charity manifest in Islamic practices according to this narration?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: How does the practice of verifying information relate to the preservation of Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer through the word of your Prophet (ﷺ) as four rak'ahs when resident, two when travelling, and one when danger is present.
question: What are the prescribed rak'ahs for prayer when a person is traveling?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer by the tongue of your Apostle (ﷺ) as two rak'ahs for the traveller, four for the resident, and one in danger.
question: How does the number of rak'ahs in prayer change based on a person's circumstances such as traveling or being in danger?

hadith-eng: I asked Ibn 'Abbas: How should I say prayer when I am in Mecca, and when I do not pray along with the Imam? He said: Two rak'ahs (of prayer) is the Sunnah of Abu'l-Qasim (ﷺ).
question: What is the significance of following the Sunnah of Abu'l-Qasim in performing prayers?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: How did the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) adhere to his practices in terms of prayer during journeys?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: How did the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) observe his practices during travel?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said four rak'ahs in the noon prayer while at Medina, but he offered two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: How does the practice of shortening prayers relate to the Prophet's actions during travel?

hadith-eng: I observed four rak'ahs in the noon prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Medina, and said two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform the noon and afternoon prayers during his travels?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas b. Malik about shortening of prayer. He said: When the Messenger of' Allah (ﷺ) had covered a distance of three miles or three farsakh (Shu'ba, one of the narrators, had some doubt about it) he observed two rak'ahs.
question: At what distance is a traveler allowed to shorten their prayers according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I went along with Shurahbil b. al-Simt to a village which was situated at a distance of seventeen or eighteen miles, and he said only two rak'ahs of prayer. I said to him (about it) and he said: I saw 'Umar observing two rak'ahs at Dhu'l-Hulaifa and I (too) said to him (about it) and he said: I am doing the same as I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing.
question: How does the practice of shortening prayers relate to the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) and his companions?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Shu'ba with the same chain of narrators and it is narrated from Simt, and the name of Shurahbil has not been mentioned, and he said that he had gone to a place called Dumin, situated at a distance of eighteen miles from Hims.
question: How does the geographical location mentioned in a hadith contribute to its context or understanding?

hadith-eng: We went out from Medina to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he prayed two rak'ahs at each time of prayer till we returned to Medina. I said: For how long did he stay in Mecca? He said: (For) ten (days).
question: What is the significance of the Prophet's (ﷺ) actions during his journey from Medina to Mecca?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: What is the significance of having multiple chains of transmission for a single hadith?

hadith-eng: I heard Anas b. Malik say: We went out for Pilgrimage from Medina. The rest is the same.
question: What can be learned from the companions' experiences during their pilgrimage journeys?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: How does the omission of specific details, like Pilgrimage, affect the understanding of a hadith?

hadith-eng: Salim b. 'Abdullah (b. 'Umar) reported on the authority of his father that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) observed the prayer of a traveller, i. e. two rak'ahs in Mina, and other places; so did Abu Bakr and 'Umar, and 'Uthman too observed two rak'ahs at the beginning of his caliphate, but he then completed four.
question: How did the practice of performing prayer as a traveler differ among the early caliphs?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Zuhri, with the same chain of transmitters, and in it mention was made of Mina only, but not of other places.
question: How do variations in hadith narrations affect the understanding of Islamic practices?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said two rak'ahs at Mina, and Abu Bakr after him, and 'Umar after Abu Bakr, and 'Uthman at the beginning of his caliphate; then 'Uthman observed four rak'ahs, and when Ibn 'Umar prayed with the Imam, he said four rak'ahs, but when he observed prayer alone, he said two rak'ahs.
question: How did the practice of performing rak'ahs at Mina change during the caliphate of 'Uthman?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its credibility?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said in Mina the prayer of a traveller (short prayer) ; Abu Bakr and 'Umar did the same and 'Uthmia did it for eight years or six years. Hafs (one of the narrators) said: Ibn 'Umar would also say two rak'ahs at Mina and then go to bed. I said to him: O uncle, I wish you could have said two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayer after shorenting the Fard prayer). He said: Were I to do that, I would have completed the prayer.
question: How did the practice of shortening prayers differ among the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: He prayed while travelling.
question: How does traveling affect the performance of obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: How did Abdullah b. Mas'ud react to 'Uthman's decision to lead four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its credibility?

hadith-eng: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) two rak'ahs and most of them offered two rak'ahs only in Mina, while the people felt secure.
question: How does the feeling of security influence the number of rak'ahs performed in prayer?

hadith-eng: I prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina, and there was the greatest number of people, and they prayed two rak'ahs on the occasion of the Farewell Pilgrimage. (Muslim said: Haritha b. Wahb al-Khuza'i is the brother of 'Ubaidullah b. 'Umar son of Khattab from the side of his mother.)
question: How does the number of people participating in a prayer affect its importance or significance in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) accommodate the needs of the community during challenging weather conditions?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: How does Islam accommodate the challenges faced by individuals during harsh weather in terms of religious obligations?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, but he did not repeat for the second time words of Ibn 'Umar (Pray in your dwellings).
question: How does the practice of calling people to prayer reflect in different circumstances?

hadith-eng: We set cut with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey when it began to rain. Upon this he said: He who desires may pray in his dwelling.
question: How does Islam accommodate the challenges faced by travelers in fulfilling their religious obligations?

hadith-eng: When you have announced" I testify that there is no god but Allah; I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," do not say:" Come to the prayer," but make this announcement:" Say prayer in your houses." He (the narrator) said that the people disapproved of it. Ibn 'Abbas said: Are you astonished at it? He (the Holy Prophet), who is better than I, did it. Jumu'a prayer is no doubt obligatory, but I do not like that I should (force you) to come out and walk in mud and slippery ground.
question: How does the practice of praying at home during difficult weather align with the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abdullah b. al-Harith say: 'Abdullah b. 'Abbas addressed us on a rainy day, and the rest of the hadith is the same, but he made no mention of Jumu'a prayer, and added: He who did it (who commanded us to say prayer in our houses), i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), is better than I.
question: How does the example of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) influence decisions made by his companions?

hadith-eng: " i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: How do variations in the narration of hadiths affect their interpretation and understanding?

hadith-eng: I do not like you should walk in muddy slippery place.
question: How does Islam prioritize the safety and well-being of individuals in the context of religious obligations?

hadith-eng: He who did it, i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), was better than I.
question: How does the example of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) influence decisions made by his followers in similar situations?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this that Ibn 'Abbas ordered his Mu'adhdhin (to summon people to prayer and then make announcement to say prayer in their houses) on Friday which was a rainy day, has been transmitted by 'Abdullah b. Harith. Wuhaib, however, says that he did not hear it from him.
question: How does Islamic tradition address the flexibility of prayer locations in specific circumstances?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to say Nafl prayer on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) adapt his prayer practices while on a journey?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) used to pray on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: What flexibility is allowed in the direction of prayer during travel according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: " So whether you turn thither is Allah's face" (ii. 115).
question: How does the practice of praying on a camel illustrate flexibility in Islamic worship?

hadith-eng: " Whether you turn thither is Allah's face," and it was revealed in this context.
question: How does the concept of Allah's omnipresence relate to the direction of prayer?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: How does the direction of prayer relate to the circumstances of travel or movement in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: I was travelling along with Ibn 'Umar on the way to Mecca. Sa'id said: When I apprehended dawn, I dismounted (the ride) and observed Witr prayer and then again joined him. Ibn 'Umar said to me: Where were you? I said: I apprehended the appearance of dawn, so I dismounted and observed Witr prayer. Upon this 'Abdullah said: Is there not a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)? I said: Yes, by Allah, and (then) he said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe Witr prayer on the camel's back.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform Witr prayer while traveling?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. Dinar reported on the authority of Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe prayer on his ride (no matter) in which direction it had its face turned. 'Abdullah b. Dinar said that Ibn 'Umar used to do like that.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate flexibility in prayer during travel?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe Witr prayer on his ride.
question: Is it permissible to perform prayers while traveling on a ride?

hadith-eng: Salim b. 'Abdullah reported on the authority of his father that the Messenger of Allah (may peace be. upon him) used to observe Nafl (supererogatory) prayer on his ride no matter in what direction it turned its face, and he observed Witr too on it, but did not observe obligatory prayer on it.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) manage his prayer routine while on a journey?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: What flexibility is allowed in the direction of prayer during travel according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: We met Anas b. Malik as he came to Syria at a place known as 'Ain-al-Tamar and saw him observing prayer on the back of his donkey with his face turned in that direction. (Hammam one of the narrators) pointed towards the left of Qibla, so I said to him: I find you observing prayer towards the side other than that of Qibla. Upon this he said: Had I not seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing like this, I would not have done so at all.
question: How does observing prayer in a direction other than the Qibla relate to the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers.
question: How does the practice of combining prayers reflect the flexibility of Islamic law during travel?

hadith-eng: Nafi' reported that when Ibn 'Umar was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers after the twilight had disappeared, and he would say that when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers.
question: Under what circumstances is it permissible to combine the Maghrib and Isha prayers?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the sunset and Isha' prayers when he was in a hurry on a journey.
question: What are the specific prayers that can be combined when one is in a hurry on a journey?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) delaying the sunset prayer till he would combine it with the 'Isha' when he hastened to set out on a journey.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) manage prayer times when preparing for a journey?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) set out on a journey before the sun declined (from the meridian), he delayed the noon prayer till the afternoon prayer, and then dismounted (his ride) and combined them (noon and afternoon prayers), but if the sun had declined before his setting out on a journey, he observed the noon prayer and then mounted (the ride).
question: What is the significance of combining prayers during a journey in Islam?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) intended to combine two prayers on a journey, he delayed the noon prayer till came the early time of the afternoon prayer, and then combined the two.
question: What are the conditions under which prayers can be combined during travel?

hadith-eng: Anas reported that when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had to set out on a journey hurriedly, he delayed the noon prayer to the earlier time for the afternoon prayer, and then he would combine them, and he would delay the sunset prayer to the time when the twilight would disappear and then combine it with the 'Isha' prayer.
question: How does the timing of prayers change when one is on a journey according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.
question: What are the conditions that allow for the combination of sunset and Isha' prayers?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together in Medina without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey. (Abu Zubair said: I asked Sa'id [one of the narrators] why he did that. He said: I asked Ibn 'Abbas as you have asked me, and he replied that he [the Holy Prophet] wanted that no one among his Ummah should be put to [unnecessary] hardship.)
question: How does the concept of avoiding hardship for the Ummah influence Islamic practices?

hadith-eng: What prompted him to do this? He said: He wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: What consideration did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) have for his Ummah when making decisions during travel?

hadith-eng: We set out with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the Tabuk expedition, and he observed the noon and afternoon prayers together and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers together.
question: How does the practice of combining prayers reflect the flexibility of Islamic rituals during expeditions?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combined in the expedition to Tabuk the noon prayer with the afternoon prayer and the sunset prayer with the 'Isha' prayer. He (one of the narrators) said: What prompted him to do that? He (Mu'adh) replied that he (the Holy Prophet) wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: What considerations did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) have for his Ummah when making decisions during expeditions?

hadith-eng: " I said to Ibn 'Abbas: What prompted him to do that? He said: So that his (Prophet's) Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship." And in the hadith transmitted by Mu'awiya (the words are):" It was said to Ibn 'Abbas: What did he intend thereby? He said he wanted that his Ummah should not be put to unnecessary hardship."
question: How does the concept of easing hardship for the Ummah reflect in the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I observed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) eight (rak'ahs) in combination, and seven rak'ahs in combination. I (one of the narrators) said: O Abd Sha'tha', I think that he (the Holy Prophet) had delayed the noon prayer and hastened the afternoon prayer, and he delayed the sunset prayer and hastened the 'Isha' prayer. He said: I also think so.
question: Under what circumstances can prayers be combined according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed in Medina seven (rak'ahs) and eight (rak'ahs), i. e. (be combined) the noon and afternoon prayers (eight rak'ahs) and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers (seven rak'ahs).
question: Under what circumstances can the noon and afternoon prayers be combined?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas one day addressed us in the afternoon (after the afternoon prayer) till the sun disappeared and the stars appeared, and the people began to say: Prayer, prayer. A person from Banu Tamim came there. He neither slackened nor turned away, but (continued crying): Prayer, prayer. Ibn 'Abbas said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach me Sunnah? And then he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the noon and afternoon prayers and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers. 'Abdullah b. Shaqiq said: Some doubt was created in my mind about it. So I came to Abu Huraira and asked him (about it) and he testified his assertion.
question: How did Ibn 'Abbas justify the practice of combining prayers based on the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: A person said to Ibn 'Abbas (as he delayed the prayer): Prayer. He kept silence. He again said: Prayer. He again kept silence, and he again cried: Prayer. He again kept silence and said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach us about prayer? We used to combine two prayers during the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: How did the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) approach the timing of prayers?

hadith-eng: None of you should give a share to Satan out of your self. He should not deem that it is necessary for him to turn but to the right only (after prayer). I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the left.
question: How does the direction of turning after prayer relate to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by A'mash, with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the consistency in the chain of transmitters affect the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas how I should turn-to the right or to the left-when I say my prayers. He said: I have very often seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the right.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) learn about the correct way to perform prayer?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) used to turn to the right (at the end of the prayer).
question: How does the direction of movement at the conclusion of prayer reflect the Sunnah of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: When we prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) we cherished to be on his right side so that his face would turn towards us (at the end of the prayer), and he (the narrator) said: I heard him say: O my Lord! save me from Thy torment on the Day when Thoil, wouldst raise or gather Thy servants.
question: What supplication did the Prophet (ﷺ) make regarding protection from torment on the Day of Judgment?

hadith-eng: " His face would turn towards us."
question: How do variations in hadith narrations affect their interpretation and understanding?

hadith-eng: When the prayer commences then there is no prayer (valid), but the obligatory prayer. This hadith has been narrated by Warqa' with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the commencement of an obligatory prayer affect other prayers being performed at that time?

hadith-eng: When the prayer commences, there is no prayer but the obligatory one.
question: How does the commencement of an obligatory prayer affect the performance of other voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Ishaq with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its credibility?

hadith-eng: I then met 'Amr (the other narrator) and he narrated it to me, but it was not transmitted directly from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: How does the reliability of narrators affect the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to pass by a person who was busy in praying while the (Fard of the) dawn prayer had commenced. He said something to him, which we do not know what it was. When we turned back we surrounded him and said: What is it that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to you? He replied: He (the Holy Prophet) had said to me that he perceived as if one of them was about to observe four (rak'ahs) of the dawn prayer. Qa'nabi reported that 'Abdullah b. Malik b. Buhaina narrated it on the authority of his father. (Abu'l-Husain Muslim said): His assertion that he has narrated this hadith on the authority of his father is not correct.
question: How should one respond if they are corrected by someone more knowledgeable during prayer?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: How does the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) address the issue of performing additional rak'ahs during the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: A person entered the mosque, while the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was leading the dawn prayer. He observed two rak'ahs in a corner of the mosque, and then joined the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) in prayer. When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had pronounced salutations (he had concluded the prayer), he said: O, so and so, which one out of these two prayers did you count (as your Fard prayer), the one that you observed alone or the prayer that you observed with us?
question: How should one prioritize between individual and congregational prayers?

hadith-eng: When any one of you enters the mosque, he should say:" O Allah! open for me the doors of Thy mercy" ; and when he steps out he should say: 'O Allah! I beg of Thee Thy Grace." (Imam Muslim said: I heard Yahya saying: I transcribed this hadith from the compilation of Sulaiman b. Bilal.)
question: What is the significance of seeking Allah's grace upon leaving the mosque?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) by Abu Usaid.
question: What is the significance of having multiple narrations of the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: When any one of you enters the mosque, he should observe two rak'ahs (of Nafl prayer) before sitting.
question: Why is it recommended to pray before sitting when entering a mosque?

hadith-eng: I entered the mosque, when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been sitting among people, and I also sat down among them. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: What prevented you from offering two rak'ahs (of Nafl prayer) before sitting down? I said: Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and people sitting (around you and I, therefore, sat in your company). He (the Holy Prophet) then said: When anyone among you enters the mosque, he should not sit till he has observed two rak'ahs.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) emphasize the importance of performing prayer upon entering a mosque?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) owed me a debt; he paid me back and made an addition (of this). I entered the mosque and he (the Holy Prophet) said to me: Observe two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: How does performing additional acts of worship relate to gratitude in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate the importance of fulfilling obligations in business transactions?

hadith-eng: I went with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on an expedition and my camel delayed me and I was exhausted. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) thus came earlier than I, whereas I came on the next day and went to the mosque and found him (the Holy Prophet) at the gate of the mosque. He said: It is now that you have come. I said. Yes. He said: Leave your camel and enter (the mosque) and observe two rak'ahs. He (the narrator) said: So I entered and observed (two rak'ahs) of prayer and then went back.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) demonstrate consideration for his companions during expeditions?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not come back from the journey but by day in the forenoon, and when he arrived, he went first to the mosque, and having prayed two rak'ahs in it he sat down in it.
question: What significance does praying two rak'ahs in the mosque hold after returning from travel?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, but when he came back from the journey.
question: Under what circumstances did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform the forenoon prayer?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: How did travel affect the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) routine prayers?

hadith-eng: I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing the supererogatory prayer of the forenoon, but I observed it. And if the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) abandoned any act which he in fact loved to do, it was out of fear that if the people practised it constantly, it might become obligatory for them.
question: What is the significance of supererogatory prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: Four rak'ahs, but sometimes more as he pleased.
question: Is there flexibility in the number of rak'ahs performed during the forenoon prayer?

hadith-eng: " As Allah pleased."
question: How do different transmitters affect the understanding of a hadith?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe four rak'ahs in the forenoon prayer and he sometimes observed more as Allah pleased.
question: Is there flexibility in the number of rak'ahs performed during the forenoon prayer?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the consistency of a hadith's chain of transmitters affect its authenticity?

hadith-eng: No one has ever narrated to me that he saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing the forenoon prayer, except Umm Hani. She, however, narrated that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) entered her house on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and prayed eight rak'ahs (adding): I never saw a shorter prayer than it except that he performed the bowing and prostration completely. But (one of the narrators) Ibn Bashshar in his narration made no mention of the word:" Never".
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform the forenoon prayer during the Conquest of Mecca?

hadith-eng: I had been asking about, as I was desirous to find one among people who should inform me, whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the forenoon prayer, but I found none to narrate that to me except Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib (the real sister of Hadrat 'Ali), who told me that on the day of the Conquest the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came (to our house) after the dawn had (sufficiently) arisen. A cloth was brought and privacy was provided for him (the Holy Prophet). He took a bath and then stood up and observed eight rak'ahs. I do not know whether his Qiyam (standing posture) was longer, or bending or prostration or all of them were of equal duration. She (Umm Hani) further said: I never saw him saying this Nafl prayer prior to it or subsequently. (Al-Muradi narrated on the authority of Yunus that he made no mention of the words:" He informed me." )
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform his prayers during the Conquest of Mecca?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform his prayers on the day of the Conquest of Mecca?

hadith-eng: Abu Murra narrated on the authority of Umm Hani that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca observed in her house eight rak'ahs of prayer in one cloth, its opposite corners having been tied from the opposite sides.
question: How does the practice of tying a cloth during prayer reflect on the flexibility of Islamic prayer attire?

hadith-eng: In the morning charity is due from every bone in the body of every one of you. Every utterance of Allah's glorification is an act of charity. Every utterance of praise of Him is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Oneness is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Greatness is an act of charity, enjoining good is an act of charity, forbidding what is distreputable is an act of charity, and two rak'ahs which one prays in the forenoon will suffice.
question: What is the significance of performing two rak'ahs in the forenoon according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: three fasts during every month, two rak'ahs of the forenoon prayer, and observing Witr prayer before going to bed.
question: How can one incorporate additional prayers into their daily routine for spiritual benefit?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: What is the significance of multiple chains of transmission in hadith literature?

hadith-eng: My friend Abu'l-Qasim (ﷺ) instructed me to do three things, and the rest of the hadith is the same.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) regard his instructions and teachings?

hadith-eng: My Friend (ﷺ) instructed me in three (acts), and I would never abandon them as long as I live. (And these three things are): Three fasts during every month, the forenoon prayer, and this that I should not sleep till I have observed the Witr prayer.
question: How can one incorporate additional prayers into their daily routine for spiritual benefit?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that Hafsa, the Mother of the Believers, informed him that when the Mu'adhdhin became silent after calling (people) to the dawn prayer, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) commenced the dawn (prayer) when it dawned by observing two short rak'ahs before the commencement of the (Fard) prayer.
question: How does the timing of the dawn prayer relate to the call of the Mu'adhdhin?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Nafi' with the same chain of narrators.
question: How does the consistency of a hadith's transmission affect its authenticity?

hadith-eng: Hafsa reported that when it was dawn, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not observe (any other prayers) but two short rak'ahs.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prioritize his prayers at the time of dawn?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Shu'ba with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its authenticity?

hadith-eng: When the dawn appeared, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayers).
question: How many rak'ahs did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform when the dawn appeared?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe two rak'ahs of Sunnah (prayer) when he heard the Adhin and shortened them.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform the Sunnah prayers in terms of length?

hadith-eng: " When it was dawn".
question: How does the timing of certain actions impact their religious or spiritual significance in Islam?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe two (supererogatory) rak'ahs in between the call to prayer and the Iqama of the dawn prayer.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) incorporate additional prayers into his daily routine?

hadith-eng: Did he recite in them Surah Fatiha (only)?
question: How does the practice of shortening prayers reflect on the flexibility of Islamic rituals?

hadith-eng: When it was dawn, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed two rak'ahs, and I would say: Does he recite only the opening chapter of the Qur'an in it?
question: What role does the recitation of the opening chapter of the Qur'an play in the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) was not so much particular about observing supererogatory rak'ahs as in case of the two rak'ahs of the dawn prayer.
question: How does the emphasis on certain supererogatory prayers reflect the Prophet's (ﷺ) practices?

hadith-eng: I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) hastening as much in observing supererogatory as two rak'ahs before the (Fard) of the dawn prayer.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) prioritize his voluntary prayers in relation to the obligatory ones?

hadith-eng: The two rak'ahs at dawn are better than this world and what it contains.
question: How does the value of the two rak'ahs at dawn compare to worldly possessions?

hadith-eng: They are dearer to me than the whole world.
question: Why might certain acts of worship be considered more valuable than worldly possessions?

hadith-eng: " Say: O unbelievers," (Qur'an, cix.) and" Say: Allah is one" (cxii.).
question: How are specific chapters of the Qur'an incorporated into the supererogatory rak'ahs of the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).
question: How does the recitation of specific Quranic verses during prayer reflect one's faith and testimony in Islam?

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).
question: What is the significance of reciting specific Quranic verses in the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by another chain of narrators.
question: How does the reliability of narrators affect the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). Some of the other narrators said the same words: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard (from so and so).
question: How does consistent observance of voluntary prayers impact one's spiritual rewards in Islam?

hadith-eng: He who observed twelve voluntary rak'ahs, a house will be built for him in Paradise.
question: How many voluntary rak'ahs are mentioned as a means to attain a house in Paradise?

hadith-eng: If any Muslim servant (of Allah) prays for the sake of Allah twelve rak'ahs (of Sunan) every day, over and above the obligatory ones, Allah will build for him a house in Paradise, or a house will be built for him in Paradise; and I have not abandoned observing them after (hearing it from the Messenger of Allah). (So said also 'Amr and Nu'man.)
question: How can performing extra prayers impact a Muslim's afterlife according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: If any Muslim servant (of Allah) performed ablution, and performed it well, and then observed every day, the rest of the hadith is the same.
question: How does regular observance of daily prayers impact a Muslim's spiritual life?

hadith-eng: I prayed along with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) two rak'ahs before and two rak'ahs after the noon prayer, two rak'ahs after the sunset prayer and two rak'ahs after the 'Isha' prayer and two rak'ahs after the Friday prayer; and so far as the sunset, 'Isha' and Friday prayers are concerned, I observed (them) along with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) in his house.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) incorporate additional prayers into his daily routine?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) incorporate different physical postures in his prayers based on his recitation?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) vary his prayer routine between standing and sitting?

hadith-eng: I fell ill in Persia and therefore, prayed in a sitting posture, and I asked 'A'isha about it and she said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) prayed for a long time in the night sitting.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform his night prayers when he was sitting?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) during the night (i. e. Tahajjud prayer) She replied: He used to pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting in the night, and when he recited the Qur'an while standing, he would bow himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow from the sitting position.
question: What is the significance of reciting the Qur'an in different postures during night prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). She said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would observe prayer (Nafl) in a standing position as well as in a sitting position, and when he commenced the prayer in a standing position, he bowed in this very position, and when he commenced the prayer in a sitting position, he bowed in this very position.
question: What flexibility is there in the positions of prayer according to the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's dedication to prayer from his practice of standing up to recite the remaining verses?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray while sitting (when he grew old) and he recited in this position and when the recitation equal to thirty or forty verses was left, he would then stand up and recite (for this duration) in a standing position and then bowed himself and then prostrated himself and did the same in the second rak'ah.
question: What is the significance of reciting a specific number of verses before changing positions in prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in sitting position (while observing the Tahajjud prayer) and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and recite (for the duration in which) a man (ordinarily) recites forty verses.
question: How does the Prophet's practice of standing up to recite additional verses before bowing influence the understanding of prayer rituals?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha how the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did in the two rak'ahs as he (observed them) sitting. She said: He would recite (the Qur'an) in them, and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and then bowed.
question: What was the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice regarding standing and bowing during prayer when he started from a sitting position?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: What is the significance of performing Nafl prayers while sitting in Islam?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: How does the testimony of companions contribute to the understanding of the Prophet's (ﷺ) actions and teachings?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) died (in this very state) that he observed most of his (Nafl) prayers in a sitting position.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform his voluntary prayers towards the end of his life?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) grew bulky and heavy he would observe (most of his Nafl) prayers sitting.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility of prayer positions in Islam from the Prophet's (ﷺ) actions?

hadith-eng: Never did I see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing supererogatory prayer sitting till one year before his death when he would observe Nafl prayer in a sitting position, and he would recite the Surah (of the Qur'an) in such a slow-measured tone (that duration of its recital) became more lengthy than the one longer than this.
question: How does the recitation speed and tone affect the experience of prayer in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: Zuhri reported this hadith with the same chain of transmitters, except this that he made a mention of one year or two years.
question: How does the mention of time periods, such as one year or two years, affect the understanding of a hadith?

hadith-eng: Jabir b. Samura reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) prayer sitting before his death.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) perform his prayers towards the end of his life?

hadith-eng: It was narrated to me that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had said: The prayer observed by a person sitting is half of the prayer. I came to him (ﷺ) and found him praying in a sitting position. I placed my hand on his head. He said: O 'Abdullah b. 'Amr, what is the matter with you? I said: Messenger of Allah, it has been narrated to me that you said: The prayer of a man in a sitting position is half of the prayer, whereas you are observing prayer sitting. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Yes, it is so, but I am not like anyone amongst you.
question: How does the status of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) differ from that of other individuals in terms of religious practices?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Yahya al-A'raj with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its credibility and acceptance?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray eleven rak'ahs at night, observing the Witr with a single rak'ah, and when he had finished them, he lay down on his right side, till the Mu'adhdhin came to him and he (the Holy Prophet) then observed two short rak'ahs (of Sunan of the dawn prayer).
question: What is the significance of observing Witr prayer in the night prayer routine?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. He replied: I wondered about it in the same way as you wonder about it, so I asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about it and he said: It is an act of charity which Allah has done to you, so accept His charity.
question: How does the concept of divine charity manifest in Islamic practices according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What is the significance of the relationship between a narrator and a caliph in the context of hadith transmission?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer by the tongue of your Apostle (ﷺ) as two rak'ahs for the traveller, four for the resident, and one in danger.
question: What is the significance of the Prophet's guidance on the prescribed number of rak'ahs for different situations?

hadith-eng: I asked Ibn 'Abbas: How should I say prayer when I am in Mecca, and when I do not pray along with the Imam? He said: Two rak'ahs (of prayer) is the Sunnah of Abu'l-Qasim (ﷺ).
question: How does the Sunnah of Abu'l-Qasim (ﷺ) influence the practice of prayer in Mecca?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the repetition of a hadith by different narrators affect its authenticity and reliability?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: How did the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) maintain the practice of performing two rak'ahs during travel?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) approach the practice of prayer during travel?

hadith-eng: We went out from Medina to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he prayed two rak'ahs at each time of prayer till we returned to Medina. I said: For how long did he stay in Mecca? He said: (For) ten (days).
question: How long did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) stay in Mecca during this journey?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: How does the presence of different narrators affect the credibility of a hadith?

hadith-eng: I heard Anas b. Malik say: We went out for Pilgrimage from Medina. The rest is the same.
question: What can be learned from the companions' experiences during their pilgrimage journey?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: How do variations in hadith narrations affect the understanding of religious practices?

hadith-eng: Salim b. 'Abdullah (b. 'Umar) reported on the authority of his father that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) observed the prayer of a traveller, i. e. two rak'ahs in Mina, and other places; so did Abu Bakr and 'Umar, and 'Uthman too observed two rak'ahs at the beginning of his caliphate, but he then completed four.
question: How did the practice of performing rak'ahs differ among the early caliphs during travel?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Zuhri, with the same chain of transmitters, and in it mention was made of Mina only, but not of other places.
question: How do variations in hadith narrations affect their interpretation and understanding?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by the same chain of transmitters.
question: How does the consistency of a hadith's narration across different transmitters affect its authenticity?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said in Mina the prayer of a traveller (short prayer) ; Abu Bakr and 'Umar did the same and 'Uthmia did it for eight years or six years. Hafs (one of the narrators) said: Ibn 'Umar would also say two rak'ahs at Mina and then go to bed. I said to him: O uncle, I wish you could have said two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayer after shorenting the Fard prayer). He said: Were I to do that, I would have completed the prayer.
question: How did the practice of shortening prayers during travel differ among the early caliphs?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: How did Abdullah b. Mas'ud react to the change in the number of rak'ahs performed at Mina?

hadith-eng: I prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina, and there was the greatest number of people, and they prayed two rak'ahs on the occasion of the Farewell Pilgrimage. (Muslim said: Haritha b. Wahb al-Khuza'i is the brother of 'Ubaidullah b. 'Umar son of Khattab from the side of his mother.)
question: How does the number of people attending a prayer affect its observance in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) accommodate the needs of the community during challenging weather?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) instruct the Mu'adhdhin regarding prayer announcements during inclement weather?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, but he did not repeat for the second time words of Ibn 'Umar (Pray in your dwellings).
question: How does the instruction to pray in one's dwelling relate to the flexibility of prayer in Islam?

hadith-eng: We set cut with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey when it began to rain. Upon this he said: He who desires may pray in his dwelling.
question: How does Islam accommodate the needs of individuals during travel or difficult circumstances?

hadith-eng: When you have announced" I testify that there is no god but Allah; I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," do not say:" Come to the prayer," but make this announcement:" Say prayer in your houses." He (the narrator) said that the people disapproved of it. Ibn 'Abbas said: Are you astonished at it? He (the Holy Prophet), who is better than I, did it. Jumu'a prayer is no doubt obligatory, but I do not like that I should (force you) to come out and walk in mud and slippery ground.
question: How does Islamic teaching prioritize the safety and well-being of individuals in the context of religious obligations?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abdullah b. al-Harith say: 'Abdullah b. 'Abbas addressed us on a rainy day, and the rest of the hadith is the same, but he made no mention of Jumu'a prayer, and added: He who did it (who commanded us to say prayer in our houses), i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), is better than I.
question: How does the hadith illustrate the flexibility of prayer arrangements in Islam during challenging circumstances?

hadith-eng: " i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: How do variations in hadith narrations affect their interpretation and understanding?

hadith-eng: He who did it, i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), was better than I.
question: How does weather conditions, like rain, affect the performance of congregational prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to say Nafl prayer on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: How does the direction of prayer affect the performance of Nafl prayers during travel?

hadith-eng: " So whether you turn thither is Allah's face" (ii. 115).
question: How does the practice of praying on a camel illustrate flexibility in Islamic prayer rituals?

hadith-eng: " Whether you turn thither is Allah's face," and it was revealed in this context.
question: How does the direction of prayer relate to the presence of Allah according to Islamic belief?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: How does the direction of prayer affect the performance of Nafl prayers according to this narration?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. Dinar reported on the authority of Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe prayer on his ride (no matter) in which direction it had its face turned. 'Abdullah b. Dinar said that Ibn 'Umar used to do like that.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) emulate his practices in their daily lives?

hadith-eng: Salim b. 'Abdullah reported on the authority of his father that the Messenger of Allah (may peace be. upon him) used to observe Nafl (supererogatory) prayer on his ride no matter in what direction it turned its face, and he observed Witr too on it, but did not observe obligatory prayer on it.
question: How does the direction of a ride affect the performance of supererogatory prayers?

hadith-eng: We met Anas b. Malik as he came to Syria at a place known as 'Ain-al-Tamar and saw him observing prayer on the back of his donkey with his face turned in that direction. (Hammam one of the narrators) pointed towards the left of Qibla, so I said to him: I find you observing prayer towards the side other than that of Qibla. Upon this he said: Had I not seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing like this, I would not have done so at all.
question: How does observing prayer in a direction other than the Qibla relate to the actions of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers.
question: What are the specific prayers that can be combined when one is in a hurry on a journey?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the sunset and Isha' prayers when he was in a hurry on a journey.
question: How does the practice of combining prayers reflect the flexibility of Islamic law during travel?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) intended to combine two prayers on a journey, he delayed the noon prayer till came the early time of the afternoon prayer, and then combined the two.
question: How does the timing of prayers change for a traveler according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: Anas reported that when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had to set out on a journey hurriedly, he delayed the noon prayer to the earlier time for the afternoon prayer, and then he would combine them, and he would delay the sunset prayer to the time when the twilight would disappear and then combine it with the 'Isha' prayer.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) manage prayer times when traveling in a hurry?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together in Medina without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey. (Abu Zubair said: I asked Sa'id [one of the narrators] why he did that. He said: I asked Ibn 'Abbas as you have asked me, and he replied that he [the Holy Prophet] wanted that no one among his Ummah should be put to [unnecessary] hardship.)
question: How does the practice of combining prayers reflect the Prophet's concern for his Ummah's well-being?

hadith-eng: What prompted him to do this? He said: He wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: What consideration did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) have for his Ummah when combining prayers?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combined in the expedition to Tabuk the noon prayer with the afternoon prayer and the sunset prayer with the 'Isha' prayer. He (one of the narrators) said: What prompted him to do that? He (Mu'adh) replied that he (the Holy Prophet) wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: What consideration did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) have for his Ummah when making decisions during expeditions?

hadith-eng: " I said to Ibn 'Abbas: What prompted him to do that? He said: So that his (Prophet's) Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship." And in the hadith transmitted by Mu'awiya (the words are):" It was said to Ibn 'Abbas: What did he intend thereby? He said he wanted that his Ummah should not be put to unnecessary hardship."
question: How does Islam address the issue of hardship in religious practices for its followers?

hadith-eng: I observed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) eight (rak'ahs) in combination, and seven rak'ahs in combination. I (one of the narrators) said: O Abd Sha'tha', I think that he (the Holy Prophet) had delayed the noon prayer and hastened the afternoon prayer, and he delayed the sunset prayer and hastened the 'Isha' prayer. He said: I also think so.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) manage the timing of prayers during certain circumstances?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas one day addressed us in the afternoon (after the afternoon prayer) till the sun disappeared and the stars appeared, and the people began to say: Prayer, prayer. A person from Banu Tamim came there. He neither slackened nor turned away, but (continued crying): Prayer, prayer. Ibn 'Abbas said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach me Sunnah?
