question: What is the role of Sahih Muslim in the compilation and classification of hadiths?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer postures from the Prophet's (ﷺ) night prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) during the night (i. e. Tahajjud prayer) She replied: He used to pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting in the night, and when he recited the Qur'an while standing, he would bow himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow from the sitting position.
question: How does the practice of bowing differ when reciting the Qur'an while standing versus sitting in prayer?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: How does the Prophet's practice of standing for the last verses of a Surah during night prayer reflect his dedication to worship?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray while sitting (when he grew old) and he recited in this position and when the recitation equal to thirty or forty verses was left, he would then stand up and recite (for this duration) in a standing position and then bowed himself and then prostrated himself and did the same in the second rak'ah.
question: How can one maintain the quality of prayer while accommodating physical limitations?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha how the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did in the two rak'ahs as he (observed them) sitting. She said: He would recite (the Qur'an) in them, and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and then bowed.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer practices from A'isha's description?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) observe changes in his prayer practices over time?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) grew bulky and heavy he would observe (most of his Nafl) prayers sitting.
question: How does the practice of sitting during Nafl prayers reflect the consideration of physical ability in Islamic worship?

hadith-eng: It was narrated to me that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had said: The prayer observed by a person sitting is half of the prayer. I came to him (ﷺ) and found him praying in a sitting position. I placed my hand on his head. He said: O 'Abdullah b. 'Amr, what is the matter with you? I said: Messenger of Allah, it has been narrated to me that you said: The prayer of a man in a sitting position is half of the prayer, whereas you are observing prayer sitting. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Yes, it is so, but I am not like anyone amongst you.
question: What are the implications of performing prayer in a sitting position on the reward or value of the prayer?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Yahya al-A'raj with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the chain of narrators in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray eleven rak'ahs at night, observing the Witr with a single rak'ah, and when he had finished them, he lay down on his right side, till the Mu'adhdhin came to him and he (the Holy Prophet) then observed two short rak'ahs (of Sunan of the dawn prayer).
question: What is the significance of the two short rak'ahs observed by the Prophet before the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), said Allah prescribed the prayer as two rak'ahs, then it was completed (to four rak'ahs) at the place of residence, but was retained in the same position in journey as it was first made obligatory.
question: How does the practice of prayer differ between a place of residence and during a journey in Islam?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. He replied: I wondered about it in the same way as you wonder about it, so I asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about it and he said: It is an act of charity which Allah has done to you, so accept His charity.
question: What was Umar b. al-Khattab's approach to understanding Quranic verses related to prayer?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What can be learned about the transmission of knowledge from the interactions between companions of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer through the word of your Prophet (ﷺ) as four rak'ahs when resident, two when travelling, and one when danger is present.
question: How does the presence of danger affect the number of rak'ahs in prayer?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: What can be learned about the practice of offering Sunnah prayers during travel from the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What guidance does Islam provide regarding the performance of additional acts of worship during travel?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to consider different narrators when studying a hadith?

hadith-eng: I heard Anas b. Malik say: We went out for Pilgrimage from Medina. The rest is the same.
question: How does the journey from Medina to Mecca for pilgrimage reflect the practices of early Muslims?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: What is the significance of consistency in the transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said two rak'ahs at Mina, and Abu Bakr after him, and 'Umar after Abu Bakr, and 'Uthman at the beginning of his caliphate; then 'Uthman observed four rak'ahs, and when Ibn 'Umar prayed with the Imam, he said four rak'ahs, but when he observed prayer alone, he said two rak'ahs.
question: What does the behavior of Ibn 'Umar indicate about following the Imam in prayer?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role does the chain of transmitters play in the classification of a hadith as Sahih?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said in Mina the prayer of a traveller (short prayer) ; Abu Bakr and 'Umar did the same and 'Uthmia did it for eight years or six years. Hafs (one of the narrators) said: Ibn 'Umar would also say two rak'ahs at Mina and then go to bed. I said to him: O uncle, I wish you could have said two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayer after shorenting the Fard prayer). He said: Were I to do that, I would have completed the prayer.
question: Why might adding additional rak'ahs to a shortened prayer be considered completing the prayer?

hadith-eng: He prayed while travelling.
question: What are the conditions under which a Muslim can perform prayers differently while on a journey?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: What instructions are given to the Mu'adhdhin regarding prayer announcements in difficult weather?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abdullah b. al-Harith say: 'Abdullah b. 'Abbas addressed us on a rainy day, and the rest of the hadith is the same, but he made no mention of Jumu'a prayer, and added: He who did it (who commanded us to say prayer in our houses), i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), is better than I.
question: What guidance does Islam provide for performing prayers during challenging weather conditions?

hadith-eng: " i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: Why is it important to verify the accuracy of hadiths through multiple sources?

hadith-eng: He who did it, i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), was better than I.
question: What considerations should be taken into account when deciding to pray at home instead of the mosque?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this that Ibn 'Abbas ordered his Mu'adhdhin (to summon people to prayer and then make announcement to say prayer in their houses) on Friday which was a rainy day, has been transmitted by 'Abdullah b. Harith. Wuhaib, however, says that he did not hear it from him.
question: What role does the Mu'adhdhin play in communicating changes to prayer arrangements due to weather conditions?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) used to pray on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: In what situations can a Muslim pray in a direction other than the Qibla?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: How does the direction of the ride affect the performance of Nafl prayers while traveling?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers.
question: How does urgency or haste during travel affect the performance of prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the sunset and Isha' prayers when he was in a hurry on a journey.
question: What are the guidelines for performing prayers when one is in a hurry during a journey?

hadith-eng: We set out with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the Tabuk expedition, and he observed the noon and afternoon prayers together and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers together.
question: What are the conditions under which Muslims are permitted to combine prayers?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas one day addressed us in the afternoon (after the afternoon prayer) till the sun disappeared and the stars appeared, and the people began to say: Prayer, prayer. A person from Banu Tamim came there. He neither slackened nor turned away, but (continued crying): Prayer, prayer. Ibn 'Abbas said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach me Sunnah? And then he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the noon and afternoon prayers and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers. 'Abdullah b. Shaqiq said: Some doubt was created in my mind about it. So I came to Abu Huraira and asked him (about it) and he testified his assertion.
question: What role do the Companions of the Prophet play in verifying and understanding Islamic practices?

hadith-eng: None of you should give a share to Satan out of your self. He should not deem that it is necessary for him to turn but to the right only (after prayer). I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the left.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's actions regarding flexibility in religious practices?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas how I should turn-to the right or to the left-when I say my prayers. He said: I have very often seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the right.
question: What role does observing the actions of the Prophet (ﷺ) play in understanding Islamic rituals?

hadith-eng: " His face would turn towards us."
question: What is the role of consistency in the narration of hadiths across different transmitters?

hadith-eng: When the prayer commences, there is no prayer but the obligatory one.
question: Why is it important to focus solely on obligatory prayers once they have started?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Ishaq with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the chain of narrators in Islamic traditions?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to pass by a person who was busy in praying while the (Fard of the) dawn prayer had commenced. He said something to him, which we do not know what it was. When we turned back we surrounded him and said: What is it that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to you? He replied: He (the Holy Prophet) had said to me that he perceived as if one of them was about to observe four (rak'ahs) of the dawn prayer. Qa'nabi reported that 'Abdullah b. Malik b. Buhaina narrated it on the authority of his father. (Abu'l-Husain Muslim said): His assertion that he has narrated this hadith on the authority of his father is not correct.
question: What can be inferred about the importance of following the Prophet's guidance in prayer practices?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What is the ruling on performing additional rak'ahs during the dawn prayer after the Iqama has been called?

hadith-eng: When any one of you enters the mosque, he should say:" O Allah! open for me the doors of Thy mercy" ; and when he steps out he should say: 'O Allah! I beg of Thee Thy Grace." (Imam Muslim said: I heard Yahya saying: I transcribed this hadith from the compilation of Sulaiman b. Bilal.)
question: How does the practice of specific supplications upon entering and exiting a mosque reflect on a Muslim's daily worship routine?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) owed me a debt; he paid me back and made an addition (of this). I entered the mosque and he (the Holy Prophet) said to me: Observe two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What is the importance of prayer in expressing thankfulness in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not come back from the journey but by day in the forenoon, and when he arrived, he went first to the mosque, and having prayed two rak'ahs in it he sat down in it.
question: Why might the Prophet (ﷺ) choose to visit the mosque first upon returning from a journey?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: What can be inferred about the flexibility of prayer routines during travel in Islam?

hadith-eng: I had been asking about, as I was desirous to find one among people who should inform me, whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the forenoon prayer, but I found none to narrate that to me except Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib (the real sister of Hadrat 'Ali), who told me that on the day of the Conquest the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came (to our house) after the dawn had (sufficiently) arisen. A cloth was brought and privacy was provided for him (the Holy Prophet). He took a bath and then stood up and observed eight rak'ahs. I do not know whether his Qiyam (standing posture) was longer, or bending or prostration or all of them were of equal duration. She (Umm Hani) further said: I never saw him saying this Nafl prayer prior to it or subsequently. (Al-Muradi narrated on the authority of Yunus that he made no mention of the words:" He informed me." )
question: What can be learned from Umm Hani's account of the Prophet's prayer habits?

hadith-eng: Abu Murra narrated on the authority of Umm Hani that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca observed in her house eight rak'ahs of prayer in one cloth, its opposite corners having been tied from the opposite sides.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's actions regarding prayer during the Conquest of Mecca?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role does Abu Huraira play in the transmission of hadiths in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: My friend Abu'l-Qasim (ﷺ) instructed me to do three things, and the rest of the hadith is the same.
question: What is the significance of following the teachings and instructions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Islam?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that Hafsa, the Mother of the Believers, informed him that when the Mu'adhdhin became silent after calling (people) to the dawn prayer, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) commenced the dawn (prayer) when it dawned by observing two short rak'ahs before the commencement of the (Fard) prayer.
question: What practices did the Prophet (ﷺ) follow before commencing the obligatory dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Nafi' with the same chain of narrators.
question: What role does a narrator play in ensuring the reliability of a hadith?

hadith-eng: Hafsa reported that when it was dawn, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not observe (any other prayers) but two short rak'ahs.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of performing specific prayers at dawn?

hadith-eng: When the dawn appeared, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayers).
question: What are the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding prayer at the time of dawn?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe two (supererogatory) rak'ahs in between the call to prayer and the Iqama of the dawn prayer.
question: What practices did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) follow in preparation for the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) hastening as much in observing supererogatory as two rak'ahs before the (Fard) of the dawn prayer.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of supererogatory prayers from his actions before the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: They are dearer to me than the whole world.
question: Why might certain acts of worship be considered more beloved to the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) than material wealth?

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).
question: What is the importance of the dawn prayer in Islam, and how does it relate to the recitation of specific Quranic verses?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by another chain of narrators.
question: Why is it important to consider the chain of narrators when studying hadith literature?

hadith-eng: He who observed twelve voluntary rak'ahs, a house will be built for him in Paradise.
question: What are the spiritual benefits associated with performing additional voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) during the night (i. e. hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). Some of the other narrators said the same words: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard (from so and so).
question: What impact does consistently observing voluntary prayers have on a believer's spiritual life?

hadith-eng: He who observed twelve voluntary rak'ahs, a house will be built for him in Paradise.
question: What are the rewards associated with observing voluntary prayers in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I prayed along with Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) two rak'ahs before and two rak'ahs after the noon prayer, two rak'ahs after the sunset prayer and two rak'ahs after the 'Isha' prayer and two rak'ahs after the Friday prayer; and so far as the sunset, 'Isha' and Friday prayers are concerned, I observed (them) along with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) in his house.
question: What is the significance of performing Sunnah prayers in addition to the obligatory ones in Islam?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What is the significance of performing additional rak'ahs after obligatory prayers according to the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: What does the practice of reciting the Qur'an in a sitting position during night prayer indicate about the flexibility in Islamic worship?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in sitting position (while observing the Tahajjud prayer) and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and recite (for the duration in which) a man (ordinarily) recites forty verses.
question: What can be inferred about the duration of recitation before bowing in prayer from the Prophet's practice?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be learned about the reliability of hadiths from the narrations of close companions of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. He replied: I wondered about it in the same way as you wonder about it, so I asked the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) about it and he said: It is an act of charity which Allah has done to you, so accept His charity.
question: What was Umar b. al-Khattab's approach to understanding the rulings related to prayer shortening?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What role does seeking advice from knowledgeable individuals play in understanding religious practices?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: What does the hadith imply about the consistency of the Prophet's companions in following his practices?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What is the significance of following the actions of the Prophet Muhammad in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I went along with Shurahbil b. al-Simt to a village which was situated at a distance of seventeen or eighteen miles, and he said only two rak'ahs of prayer. I said to him (about it) and he said: I saw 'Umar observing two rak'ahs at Dhu'l-Hulaifa and I (too) said to him (about it) and he said: I am doing the same as I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing.
question: What role does the example of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) play in the decisions of his companions regarding religious practices?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to consider various narrators when studying hadith literature?

hadith-eng: He prayed while travelling.
question: What are the considerations for performing prayers when one is on a journey?

hadith-eng: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) two rak'ahs and most of them offered two rak'ahs only in Mina, while the people felt secure.
question: What can be learned about the practice of shortening prayers during travel from this narration?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: What instructions did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) give regarding prayer during travel in inclement weather?

hadith-eng: We set cut with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey when it began to rain. Upon this he said: He who desires may pray in his dwelling.
question: What options are available for Muslims regarding prayer when faced with adverse weather conditions?

hadith-eng: When you have announced" I testify that there is no god but Allah; I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," do not say:" Come to the prayer," but make this announcement:" Say prayer in your houses." He (the narrator) said that the people disapproved of it. Ibn 'Abbas said: Are you astonished at it? He (the Holy Prophet), who is better than I, did it. Jumu'a prayer is no doubt obligatory, but I do not like that I should (force you) to come out and walk in mud and slippery ground.
question: What is the significance of flexibility in religious practices during challenging circumstances according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: " i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: Why is it important to verify the accuracy of a hadith's transmission?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this that Ibn 'Abbas ordered his Mu'adhdhin (to summon people to prayer and then make announcement to say prayer in their houses) on Friday which was a rainy day, has been transmitted by 'Abdullah b. Harith. Wuhaib, however, says that he did not hear it from him.
question: What role do announcements play in guiding the community during prayer times in challenging weather?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) used to pray on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: What are the considerations for performing prayers while on a journey in Islam?

hadith-eng: " So whether you turn thither is Allah's face" (ii. 115).
question: What is the meaning of the verse 'So whether you turn thither is Allah's face' in the context of prayer?

hadith-eng: " Whether you turn thither is Allah's face," and it was revealed in this context.
question: What context led to the revelation of the verse 'Whether you turn thither is Allah's face'?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practices during travel from this narration?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Umar reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe Witr prayer on his ride.
question: What can be learned about the permissibility of performing prayers on a ride from the Prophet's practice?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: In what ways can a person maintain their spiritual practices while traveling?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together in Medina without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey. (Abu Zubair said: I asked Sa'id [one of the narrators] why he did that. He said: I asked Ibn 'Abbas as you have asked me, and he replied that he [the Holy Prophet] wanted that no one among his Ummah should be put to [unnecessary] hardship.)
question: What are the implications of the Prophet's actions in Medina for the flexibility of prayer times?

hadith-eng: What prompted him to do this? He said: He wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: How does Islam address the issue of hardship in religious practices during travel?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combined in the expedition to Tabuk the noon prayer with the afternoon prayer and the sunset prayer with the 'Isha' prayer. He (one of the narrators) said: What prompted him to do that? He (Mu'adh) replied that he (the Holy Prophet) wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: What considerations are taken into account in Islamic jurisprudence to ease the practice of religion for the community?

hadith-eng: A person said to Ibn 'Abbas (as he delayed the prayer): Prayer. He kept silence. He again said: Prayer. He again kept silence, and he again cried: Prayer. He again kept silence and said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach us about prayer? We used to combine two prayers during the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be inferred about the flexibility of prayer times during the Prophet's era?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by A'mash, with the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role does the chain of transmitters play in the classification of a hadith as Sahih?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas how I should turn-to the right or to the left-when I say my prayers. He said: I have very often seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the right.
question: What is the significance of observing the actions of the Prophet (ﷺ) in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: When we prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) we cherished to be on his right side so that his face would turn towards us (at the end of the prayer), and he (the narrator) said: I heard him say: O my Lord! save me from Thy torment on the Day when Thoil, wouldst raise or gather Thy servants.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) express their desire to be close to him during prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to pass by a person who was busy in praying while the (Fard of the) dawn prayer had commenced. He said something to him, which we do not know what it was. When we turned back we surrounded him and said: What is it that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to you? He replied: He (the Holy Prophet) had said to me that he perceived as if one of them was about to observe four (rak'ahs) of the dawn prayer. Qa'nabi reported that 'Abdullah b. Malik b. Buhaina narrated it on the authority of his father. (Abu'l-Husain Muslim said): His assertion that he has narrated this hadith on the authority of his father is not correct.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's guidance on prayer practices from this incident?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What is the importance of adhering to the prescribed number of rak'ahs in obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) by Abu Usaid.
question: How are hadiths authenticated and referenced in Islamic literature?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's actions regarding the integration of worship and daily life activities?

hadith-eng: I went with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on an expedition and my camel delayed me and I was exhausted. The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) thus came earlier than I, whereas I came on the next day and went to the mosque and found him (the Holy Prophet) at the gate of the mosque. He said: It is now that you have come. I said. Yes. He said: Leave your camel and enter (the mosque) and observe two rak'ahs. He (the narrator) said: So I entered and observed (two rak'ahs) of prayer and then went back.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) approach to addressing the needs and challenges of his companions?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not come back from the journey but by day in the forenoon, and when he arrived, he went first to the mosque, and having prayed two rak'ahs in it he sat down in it.
question: Why did the Prophet prioritize visiting the mosque upon returning from travel?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, but when he came back from the journey.
question: How did 'A'isha describe the Prophet's (ﷺ) routine concerning the forenoon prayer during travel?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) travel habits and their impact on his prayer schedule?

hadith-eng: Four rak'ahs, but sometimes more as he pleased.
question: What is the significance of the forenoon prayer in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe four rak'ahs in the forenoon prayer and he sometimes observed more as Allah pleased.
question: What does this narration suggest about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith from different transmitters?

hadith-eng: In the morning charity is due from every bone in the body of every one of you. Every utterance of Allah's glorification is an act of charity. Every utterance of praise of Him is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Oneness is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Greatness is an act of charity, enjoining good is an act of charity, forbidding what is distreputable is an act of charity, and two rak'ahs which one prays in the forenoon will suffice.
question: What is the significance of performing two rak'ahs in the forenoon according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role do narrators play in preserving the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: My Friend (ﷺ) instructed me in three (acts), and I would never abandon them as long as I live. (And these three things are): Three fasts during every month, the forenoon prayer, and this that I should not sleep till I have observed the Witr prayer.
question: What is the significance of fasting three days each month in Islam?

hadith-eng: Hafsa reported that when it was dawn, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did not observe (any other prayers) but two short rak'ahs.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from his actions at dawn?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Shu'ba with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: " When it was dawn".
question: What is the importance of the chain of transmitters in the authenticity of a hadith?

hadith-eng: " Say: O unbelievers," (Qur'an, cix.) and" Say: Allah is one" (cxii.).
question: What is the significance of reciting Surah Al-Kafirun and Surah Al-Ikhlas in the context of Islamic prayers?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).
question: What is the role of reciting Quranic verses in enhancing the spiritual experience during prayer?

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).
question: What is the significance of the verse inviting people to a common word in interfaith dialogue?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What is the significance of performing additional rak'ahs after obligatory prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha how the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did in the two rak'ahs as he (observed them) sitting. She said: He would recite (the Qur'an) in them, and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and then bowed.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from his actions during the two rak'ahs?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer positions from the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What role do companions play in preserving the teachings of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: Zuhri reported this hadith with the same chain of transmitters, except this that he made a mention of one year or two years.
question: Why might different narrators report slight variations in the details of a hadith?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), said Allah prescribed the prayer as two rak'ahs, then it was completed (to four rak'ahs) at the place of residence, but was retained in the same position in journey as it was first made obligatory.
question: How does the practice of prayer differ between a place of residence and during travel in Islam?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. question: What does this narration teach about the flexibility and mercy in Islamic practices during times of safety and security?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What role does dialogue play in the transmission and understanding of religious teachings?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer through the word of your Prophet (ﷺ) as four rak'ahs when resident, two when travelling, and one when danger is present.

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role does the chain of transmitters play in the preservation and transmission of Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. question: What is the importance of performing only the prescribed number of rak'ahs during travel according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What is the significance of following the example of the Prophet in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said four rak'ahs in the noon prayer while at Medina, but he offered two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: How does the practice of shortening prayers relate to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I observed four rak'ahs in the noon prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Medina, and said two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice regarding the number of rak'ahs in specific prayers?

hadith-eng: I heard Anas b. Malik say: We went out for Pilgrimage from Medina. The rest is the same.
question: How does the journey for pilgrimage from Medina reflect the practices of early Muslims?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Zuhri, with the same chain of transmitters, and in it mention was made of Mina only, but not of other places.
question: Why might certain locations be emphasized in religious narrations over others?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the sources of hadiths in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: What can be inferred about Abdullah b. Mas'ud's view on the number of rak'ahs to be performed at Mina?

hadith-eng: When you have announced" I testify that there is no god but Allah; I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," do not say:" Come to the prayer," but make this announcement:" Say prayer in your houses." He (the narrator) said that the people disapproved of it. Ibn 'Abbas said: Are you astonished at it? He (the Holy Prophet), who is better than I, did it. Jumu'a prayer is no doubt obligatory, but I do not like that I should (force you) to come out and walk in mud and slippery ground.
question: What is the significance of the flexibility in the call to prayer during challenging circumstances?

hadith-eng: He who did it, i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), was better than I.

question: What does this narration suggest about the practice of voluntary prayers during a journey?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) intended to combine two prayers on a journey, he delayed the noon prayer till came the early time of the afternoon prayer, and then combined the two.
question: What are the conditions under which prayers can be combined according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.
question: What are the implications of combining prayers on regular prayer timings?

hadith-eng: What prompted him to do this? He said: He wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: How does Islam address the issue of hardship for its followers in the context of prayer obligations?

hadith-eng: " I said to Ibn 'Abbas: What prompted him to do that? He said: So that his (Prophet's) Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship." And in the hadith transmitted by Mu'awiya (the words are):" It was said to Ibn 'Abbas: What did he intend thereby? He said he wanted that his Ummah should not be put to unnecessary hardship."
question: What considerations did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) have for his Ummah when making decisions about prayer practices?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed in Medina seven (rak'ahs) and eight (rak'ahs), i. e. (be combined) the noon and afternoon prayers (eight rak'ahs) and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers (seven rak'ahs).
question: How does the practice of combining prayers reflect the flexibility of Islamic prayer times?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas one day addressed us in the afternoon (after the afternoon prayer) till the sun disappeared and the stars appeared, and the people began to say: Prayer, prayer. A person from Banu Tamim came there. He neither slackened nor turned away, but (continued crying): Prayer, prayer. Ibn 'Abbas said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach me Sunnah? And then he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the noon and afternoon prayers and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers. 'Abdullah b. Shaqiq said: Some doubt was created in my mind about it. So I came to Abu Huraira and asked him (about it) and he testified his assertion.
question: What role does testimony from other companions play in confirming the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: A person said to Ibn 'Abbas (as he delayed the prayer): Prayer. He kept silence. He again said: Prayer. He again kept silence, and he again cried: Prayer. He again kept silence and said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach us about prayer? We used to combine two prayers during the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be inferred about the flexibility of prayer times during the Prophet's life?

hadith-eng: " His face would turn towards us."
question: Why is it important to note differences in details when comparing hadiths from different narrators?

At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.

hadith-eng: I had been asking about, as I was desirous to find one among people who should inform me, whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the forenoon prayer, but I found none to narrate that to me except Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib (the real sister of Hadrat 'Ali), who told me that on the day of the Conquest the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came (to our house) after the dawn had (sufficiently) arisen. A cloth was brought and privacy was provided for him (the Holy Prophet). He took a bath and then stood up and observed eight rak'ahs. I do not know whether his Qiyam (standing posture) was longer, or bending or prostration or all of them were of equal duration. She (Umm Hani) further said: I never saw him saying this Nafl prayer prior to it or subsequently. (Al-Muradi narrated on the authority of Yunus that he made no mention of the words:" He informed me." )
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from Umm Hani's narration?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) set out on a journey before the sun declined (from the meridian), he delayed the noon prayer till the afternoon prayer, and then dismounted (his ride) and combined them (noon and afternoon prayers), but if the sun had declined before his setting out on a journey, he observed the noon prayer and then mounted (the ride).
question: What considerations are made for prayer times when embarking on a journey in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.
