question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer positions from the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) practice?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) observe and report changes in his prayer practices over time?

hadith-eng: The prayer was prescribed as consisting of two rak'ahs, the prayer in travelling remained the same, but the prayer at the place of residence was completed. (Zuhri said he asked 'Urwa why 'A'isha said prayer in the complete form during journey, and he replied that she interpreted the matter herself as 'Uthman did.)
question: What is the significance of personal interpretation in religious practices according to this narration?

hadith-eng: Allah has prescribed the prayer by the tongue of your Apostle (ﷺ) as two rak'ahs for the traveller, four for the resident, and one in danger.
question: How does Islamic law accommodate different situations such as travel and danger in the practice of prayer?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What is the significance of following the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) as a model for behavior in Islam?

hadith-eng: I observed four rak'ahs in the noon prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Medina, and said two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: What can be learned from the practice of the Prophet (ﷺ) regarding the noon and afternoon prayers?

hadith-eng: We went out from Medina to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he prayed two rak'ahs at each time of prayer till we returned to Medina. I said: For how long did he stay in Mecca? He said: (For) ten (days).
question: What is the practice of performing two rak'ahs during travel according to the Prophet's tradition?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role do different transmitters play in preserving the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) said in Mina the prayer of a traveller (short prayer) ; Abu Bakr and 'Umar did the same and 'Uthmia did it for eight years or six years. Hafs (one of the narrators) said: Ibn 'Umar would also say two rak'ahs at Mina and then go to bed. I said to him: O uncle, I wish you could have said two rak'ahs (of Sunnah prayer after shorenting the Fard prayer). He said: Were I to do that, I would have completed the prayer.
question: Why might adding Sunnah prayers after the shortened Fard prayer be considered completing the prayer?

hadith-eng: He prayed while travelling.
question: What are the considerations for Muslims regarding prayer obligations when they are on a journey?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the chain of transmitters in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina, and there was the greatest number of people, and they prayed two rak'ahs on the occasion of the Farewell Pilgrimage. (Muslim said: Haritha b. Wahb al-Khuza'i is the brother of 'Ubaidullah b. 'Umar son of Khattab from the side of his mother.)
question: What can be learned from the practice of praying behind the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) during Hajj?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: What instructions did the Prophet give regarding prayer announcements during inclement weather?

hadith-eng: We met Anas b. Malik as he came to Syria at a place known as 'Ain-al-Tamar and saw him observing prayer on the back of his donkey with his face turned in that direction. (Hammam one of the narrators) pointed towards the left of Qibla, so I said to him: I find you observing prayer towards the side other than that of Qibla. Upon this he said: Had I not seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing like this, I would not have done so at all.
question: What are the conditions under which a Muslim may pray in a direction other than the Qibla?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Ishaq with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the sources of hadiths in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to pass by a person who was busy in praying while the (Fard of the) dawn prayer had commenced. He said something to him, which we do not know what it was. When we turned back we surrounded him and said: What is it that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to you? He replied: He (the Holy Prophet) had said to me that he perceived as if one of them was about to observe four (rak'ahs) of the dawn prayer. Qa'nabi reported that 'Abdullah b. Malik b. Buhaina narrated it on the authority of his father. (Abu'l-Husain Muslim said): His assertion that he has narrated this hadith on the authority of his father is not correct.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's guidance on performing additional rak'ahs during the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What can be inferred about the timing of voluntary prayers in relation to the commencement of obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: When any one of you enters the mosque, he should observe two rak'ahs (of Nafl prayer) before sitting.
question: How does performing Nafl prayers in the mosque reflect on one's respect for the place of worship?

hadith-eng: I entered the mosque, when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been sitting among people, and I also sat down among them. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: What prevented you from offering two rak'ahs (of Nafl prayer) before sitting down? I said: Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and people sitting (around you and I, therefore, sat in your company). He (the Holy Prophet) then said: When anyone among you enters the mosque, he should not sit till he has observed two rak'ahs.
question: What does this narration teach about the etiquette of entering a mosque?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) owed me a debt; he paid me back and made an addition (of this). I entered the mosque and he (the Holy Prophet) said to me: Observe two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What is the importance of performing prayer after completing a financial transaction?

hadith-eng: Four rak'ahs, but sometimes more as he pleased.
question: What does the practice of the Prophet (ﷺ) indicate about personal discretion in voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the consistency of a hadith's narration through different transmitters?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).
question: What is the importance of the forenoon prayer in Islam?

hadith-eng: Abu Murra narrated on the authority of Umm Hani that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca observed in her house eight rak'ahs of prayer in one cloth, its opposite corners having been tied from the opposite sides.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's actions on the day of the Conquest of Mecca regarding prayer?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role do narrators like Abu Huraira play in the preservation and transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: Did he recite in them Surah Fatiha (only)?
question: What might be the reasons for the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) to shorten the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: I have never seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) hastening as much in observing supererogatory as two rak'ahs before the (Fard) of the dawn prayer.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice regarding the timing and importance of voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by another chain of narrators.
question: Why is it important to reference the source of a hadith in Islamic scholarship?

hadith-eng: If any Muslim servant (of Allah) performed ablution, and performed it well, and then observed every day, the rest of the hadith is the same.
question: What are the benefits of maintaining a consistent prayer schedule for a Muslim?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) practice of Witr prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Yahya al-A'raj with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the chain of narrators in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: What is the importance of adhering to the Sunnah in the context of performing additional prayers during travel?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to compare different versions of a hadith in Islamic scholarship?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: What is the significance of consistency in hadith narrations regarding religious duties?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: What can be inferred about the importance of following the Prophet's example in prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abdullah b. al-Harith say: 'Abdullah b. 'Abbas addressed us on a rainy day, and the rest of the hadith is the same, but he made no mention of Jumu'a prayer, and added: He who did it (who commanded us to say prayer in our houses), i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), is better than I.
question: What can be learned about the humility of leaders from the statement regarding the Prophet's actions?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this that Ibn 'Abbas ordered his Mu'adhdhin (to summon people to prayer and then make announcement to say prayer in their houses) on Friday which was a rainy day, has been transmitted by 'Abdullah b. Harith. Wuhaib, however, says that he did not hear it from him.
question: What is the significance of following the guidance of religious leaders in matters of prayer during adverse conditions?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: What does this narration indicate about the practice of Nafl prayers during a journey?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was in a state of hurry on a journey, he combined the sunset and 'Isha' prayers.
question: How does the urgency of travel affect the performance of daily prayers in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) set out on a journey before the sun declined (from the meridian), he delayed the noon prayer till the afternoon prayer, and then dismounted (his ride) and combined them (noon and afternoon prayers), but if the sun had declined before his setting out on a journey, he observed the noon prayer and then mounted (the ride).
question: What are the conditions under which the Prophet (ﷺ) combined the noon and afternoon prayers during travel?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) actions regarding prayer times when not in fear or travel?

hadith-eng: " I said to Ibn 'Abbas: What prompted him to do that? He said: So that his (Prophet's) Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship." And in the hadith transmitted by Mu'awiya (the words are):" It was said to Ibn 'Abbas: What did he intend thereby? He said he wanted that his Ummah should not be put to unnecessary hardship."
question: What lessons can be learned from the Prophet's actions regarding the flexibility of prayer times?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Abbas reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed in Medina seven (rak'ahs) and eight (rak'ahs), i. e. (be combined) the noon and afternoon prayers (eight rak'ahs) and the sunset and 'Isha' prayers (seven rak'ahs).
question: What are the specific prayers mentioned in the hadith that were combined by the Prophet (ﷺ) in Medina?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas how I should turn-to the right or to the left-when I say my prayers. He said: I have very often seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the right.
question: What guidance does Islamic tradition provide regarding the direction to face after prayer?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What does this incident teach about the timing and structure of obligatory prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practices upon returning to Medina after a journey?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, but when he came back from the journey.
question: How does travel influence the prayer practices of a Muslim according to the Prophet's (ﷺ) example?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from his wife's observations?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).
question: What is the importance of performing prayers after completing a bath according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: In the morning charity is due from every bone in the body of every one of you. Every utterance of Allah's glorification is an act of charity. Every utterance of praise of Him is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Oneness is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Greatness is an act of charity, enjoining good is an act of charity, forbidding what is distreputable is an act of charity, and two rak'ahs which one prays in the forenoon will suffice.
question: How does performing two rak'ahs in the forenoon relate to fulfilling the obligation of charity?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe two rak'ahs of Sunnah (prayer) when he heard the Adhin and shortened them.
question: What does the practice of shortening Sunnah prayers indicate about the Prophet's approach to prayer?

hadith-eng: " When it was dawn".
question: What are the implications of specific times being mentioned in hadiths for Islamic rituals or prayers?

hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). Some of the other narrators said the same words: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard (from so and so).
question: What are the benefits of building a house in Paradise according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: He who observed twelve voluntary rak'ahs, a house will be built for him in Paradise.
question: What rewards are associated with performing additional prayers beyond the obligatory ones?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). She said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would observe prayer (Nafl) in a standing position as well as in a sitting position, and when he commenced the prayer in a standing position, he bowed in this very position, and when he commenced the prayer in a sitting position, he bowed in this very position.
question: How does the Prophet's method of bowing relate to the position in which he started his prayer?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: What does this narration indicate about the flexibility in the manner of performing night prayers in Islam?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be learned from the interactions between the companions and the wives of the Prophet regarding his teachings?

hadith-eng: When the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) grew bulky and heavy he would observe (most of his Nafl) prayers sitting.
question: How does the practice of sitting during prayer reflect the consideration of physical limitations in Islamic worship?

hadith-eng: Never did I see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing supererogatory prayer sitting till one year before his death when he would observe Nafl prayer in a sitting position, and he would recite the Surah (of the Qur'an) in such a slow-measured tone (that duration of its recital) became more lengthy than the one longer than this.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) manner of reciting the Qur'an during prayers?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: Why might certain elements be omitted in different narrations of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said two rak'ahs at Mina, and Abu Bakr after him, and 'Umar after Abu Bakr, and 'Uthman at the beginning of his caliphate; then 'Uthman observed four rak'ahs, and when Ibn 'Umar prayed with the Imam, he said four rak'ahs, but when he observed prayer alone, he said two rak'ahs.
question: What was Ibn 'Umar's practice regarding the number of rak'ahs when praying alone versus with the Imam?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: What can be inferred about Abdullah b. Mas'ud's view on the number of rak'ahs performed at Mina?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by A'mash with the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role does the consistency of narration play in the preservation of Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: What considerations are given to the safety and comfort of worshippers in Islam during harsh weather?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: What is the role of the Mu'adhdhin in conveying messages related to prayer during specific circumstances?

hadith-eng: " So whether you turn thither is Allah's face" (ii. 115).
question: What does the verse 'So wherever you turn, there is Allah's face' imply about the presence of Allah in Islam?

hadith-eng: " Whether you turn thither is Allah's face," and it was revealed in this context.
question: In what context was the verse 'Whether you turn thither is Allah's face' revealed, and what does it imply?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: How does the mode of transportation affect the performance of prayer in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. Dinar reported on the authority of Ibn 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe prayer on his ride (no matter) in which direction it had its face turned. 'Abdullah b. Dinar said that Ibn 'Umar used to do like that.
question: What practices did Ibn 'Umar adopt from the Prophet (ﷺ) regarding prayer on a journey?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: In what ways can a person maintain their spiritual practices while on a journey?

hadith-eng: What prompted him to do this? He said: He wanted that his Ummah should not be put to (unnecessary) hardship.
question: How does the combination of prayers reflect the Prophet's concern for avoiding hardship for his followers?

hadith-eng: None of you should give a share to Satan out of your self. He should not deem that it is necessary for him to turn but to the right only (after prayer). I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the left.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice regarding turning after prayer?

hadith-eng: When any one of you enters the mosque, he should say:" O Allah! open for me the doors of Thy mercy" ; and when he steps out he should say: 'O Allah! I beg of Thee Thy Grace." (Imam Muslim said: I heard Yahya saying: I transcribed this hadith from the compilation of Sulaiman b. Bilal.)
question: How does the practice of making specific supplications upon entering and exiting a mosque reflect on a Muslim's daily routine?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What can be learned about the relationship between commerce and spirituality from this event?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe four rak'ahs in the forenoon prayer and he sometimes observed more as Allah pleased.
question: What does this practice of the Prophet (ﷺ) indicate about the nature of voluntary prayers?

hadith-eng: My Friend (ﷺ) instructed me in three (acts), and I would never abandon them as long as I live. (And these three things are): Three fasts during every month, the forenoon prayer, and this that I should not sleep till I have observed the Witr prayer.
question: Why is the Witr prayer considered significant in the daily routine of a Muslim?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Nafi' with the same chain of narrators.
question: Why is it important to maintain the same chain of narrators when transmitting a hadith?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe two (supererogatory) rak'ahs in between the call to prayer and the Iqama of the dawn prayer.
question: What practices did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) follow in relation to the dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).
question: What is the significance of the verses from Surah Al-i-'Imran in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by another chain of narrators.
question: Why is it important to have various sources for a single hadith in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What is the significance of the Witr prayer in the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) nightly routine?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer postures from the Prophet's practice during night prayers?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: How does the Prophet's practice of standing for the last verses of a Surah reflect on the importance of certain parts of the prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in sitting position (while observing the Tahajjud prayer) and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and recite (for the duration in which) a man (ordinarily) recites forty verses.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's method of recitation in terms of the duration and manner of performing Tahajjud prayer?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: How did A'isha describe the changes in the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits as he aged?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What role do companions play in preserving the teachings and practices of the Prophet (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Qatada with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to verify the sources of hadiths in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: He prayed while travelling.

hadith-eng: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) two rak'ahs and most of them offered two rak'ahs only in Mina, while the people felt secure.

question: How can one maintain their prayer routine while on a journey according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I was travelling along with Ibn 'Umar on the way to Mecca. Sa'id said: When I apprehended dawn, I dismounted (the ride) and observed Witr prayer and then again joined him. Ibn 'Umar said to me: Where were you? I said: I apprehended the appearance of dawn, so I dismounted and observed Witr prayer. Upon this 'Abdullah said: Is there not a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)? I said: Yes, by Allah, and (then) he said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe Witr prayer on the camel's back.
question: What considerations should be taken into account when performing prayers during travel according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) combining the sunset and Isha' prayers when he was in a hurry on a journey.
question: How does urgency during travel affect the performance of prayers in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: A person said to Ibn 'Abbas (as he delayed the prayer): Prayer. He kept silence. He again said: Prayer. He again kept silence, and he again cried: Prayer. He again kept silence and said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach us about prayer? We used to combine two prayers during the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be inferred about the flexibility of prayer times from the practices during the Prophet's era?

hadith-eng: " His face would turn towards us."
question: What role does the physical demeanor of the Prophet play in the transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: When the prayer commences, there is no prayer but the obligatory one.
question: What are the implications of focusing solely on obligatory prayers during their designated times?

hadith-eng: I entered the mosque, when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been sitting among people, and I also sat down among them. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: What prevented you from offering two rak'ahs (of Nafl prayer) before sitting down? I said: Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and people sitting (around you and I, therefore, sat in your company). He (the Holy Prophet) then said: When anyone among you enters the mosque, he should not sit till he has observed two rak'ahs.
question: Why might someone refrain from performing additional prayers upon entering a mosque, and how does the Prophet (ﷺ) address this?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) flexibility in prayer routines during travel?

hadith-eng: Four rak'ahs, but sometimes more as he pleased.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) practice regarding the forenoon prayer from this narration?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe four rak'ahs in the forenoon prayer and he sometimes observed more as Allah pleased.
question: What does the forenoon prayer signify in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: I had been asking about, as I was desirous to find one among people who should inform me, whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the forenoon prayer, but I found none to narrate that to me except Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib (the real sister of Hadrat 'Ali), who told me that on the day of the Conquest the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came (to our house) after the dawn had (sufficiently) arisen. A cloth was brought and privacy was provided for him (the Holy Prophet). He took a bath and then stood up and observed eight rak'ahs. I do not know whether his Qiyam (standing posture) was longer, or bending or prostration or all of them were of equal duration. She (Umm Hani) further said: I never saw him saying this Nafl prayer prior to it or subsequently. (Al-Muradi narrated on the authority of Yunus that he made no mention of the words:" He informed me." )
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's prayer habits from Umm Hani's narration?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).
question: What is the importance of performing prayers after completing a bath in Islam?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: How does the authenticity of a hadith get affected by different chains of narration?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that Hafsa, the Mother of the Believers, informed him that when the Mu'adhdhin became silent after calling (people) to the dawn prayer, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) commenced the dawn (prayer) when it dawned by observing two short rak'ahs before the commencement of the (Fard) prayer.
question: What role do the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) play in guiding the practice of dawn prayer?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) was not so much particular about observing supererogatory rak'ahs as in case of the two rak'ahs of the dawn prayer.
question: How does the emphasis on certain supererogatory prayers reflect on a person's spiritual discipline?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).
question: What is the significance of affirming belief in Allah and identifying as a Muslim during prayer?

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).
question: What is the importance of finding common ground in religious beliefs according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). Some of the other narrators said the same words: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard (from so and so).
question: How did Umm Habiba demonstrate her commitment to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) dedication to prayer from his practice of praying both before and after obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer postures from the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) night prayers?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What role does 'A'isha play in the transmission of hadiths related to the Prophet's practices?

hadith-eng: Never did I see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing supererogatory prayer sitting till one year before his death when he would observe Nafl prayer in a sitting position, and he would recite the Surah (of the Qur'an) in such a slow-measured tone (that duration of its recital) became more lengthy than the one longer than this.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of sitting during Nafl prayers towards the end of his life?

hadith-eng: Jabir b. Samura reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) prayer sitting before his death.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility of prayer positions in Islam from this narration?

hadith-eng: The prayer was prescribed as two rak'ahs, two rak'ahs both in journey and at the place of residence. The prayer while travelling remained as it was (originally prescribed), but an addition was made in the prayer (observed) at the place of residence.
question: How does the practice of prayer differ between traveling and residing in one place in Islam?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said four rak'ahs in the noon prayer while at Medina, but he offered two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) adjust his prayer routine when traveling?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Anas by another chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to consider different chains of transmitters when studying hadiths?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abd al-Rahman as saying; 'Uthman led us four rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. It was reported to Abdullah b. Mas'ud and he recited:" Surely we are Allah's and to Him shall we return," and then said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina two rak'ahs of prayer. I prayed along with Abu Bakr al-Siddiq two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I prayed along with 'Umar b. Khattab two rak'ahs of prayer at Mina. I wish I had my share of the two rak'ahs acceptable (to God) for the four rak'ahs.
question: What can be inferred about the consistency of prayer practices during the time of the Prophet and his companions from this narration?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: What considerations should be taken into account for communal prayers during inclement weather?

hadith-eng: " i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)."
question: Why is it important to specify the source when narrating a hadith?

hadith-eng: Ibn 'Umar reported that the Apostle (ﷺ) used to pray on (the back of) his camel in whatever direction it took him.
question: How does the practice of the Prophet (ﷺ) illustrate the adaptability of prayer in different circumstances?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.
question: What are the implications of combining prayers on the regularity of daily prayer times?

hadith-eng: I asked Anas how I should turn-to the right or to the left-when I say my prayers. He said: I have very often seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) turning to the right.
question: What can be learned from the companions about the Prophet's (ﷺ) actions during prayer rituals?

hadith-eng: " His face would turn towards us."
question: Why is it important to consider variations in hadith narrations when studying Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: When the prayer commences, there is no prayer but the obligatory one.

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) interactions with his companions from his actions after buying a camel?

hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. I gave him salutation and he said: Who is she? I said: It is Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib. He (the Holy Prophet) said: Greeting for Umm Hani. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).
question: What is the importance of the forenoon prayer in the context of this event?

hadith-eng: " When it was dawn".
question: What are the implications of specific times mentioned in hadiths for daily Islamic practices?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).
question: What is the importance of affirming one's faith and identity as a Muslim in daily prayers?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by another chain of narrators.

hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). Some of the other narrators said the same words: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard (from so and so).
question: What are the benefits of maintaining regular voluntary prayers as mentioned in Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: What can be learned about the flexibility in prayer postures from the Prophet's night prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). She said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would observe prayer (Nafl) in a standing position as well as in a sitting position, and when he commenced the prayer in a standing position, he bowed in this very position, and when he commenced the prayer in a sitting position, he bowed in this very position.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of prayer from A'isha's narration?

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.
question: How does the Prophet's practice of standing for the last verses of a Surah during night prayer reflect on the importance of physical posture in prayer?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to recite in sitting position (while observing the Tahajjud prayer) and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and recite (for the duration in which) a man (ordinarily) recites forty verses.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) dedication to prayer from his practice of reciting forty verses before bowing?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.
question: How did the companions of the Prophet (ﷺ) perceive changes in his prayer practices over time?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Yahya al-A'raj with the same chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to have multiple narrations of the same hadith from different transmitters?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What role did Umar ibn al-Khattab play in the transmission of Islamic knowledge?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: What is the importance of performing only the obligatory prayers during travel according to the companions of the Prophet?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What is the significance of following the example of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been reported by Zuhri, with the same chain of transmitters, and in it mention was made of Mina only, but not of other places.
question: How does the consistency of a hadith's content across different narrations affect its reliability?

hadith-eng: I heard 'Abdullah b. al-Harith say: 'Abdullah b. 'Abbas addressed us on a rainy day, and the rest of the hadith is the same, but he made no mention of Jumu'a prayer, and added: He who did it (who commanded us to say prayer in our houses), i. e. the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), is better than I.
question: What can be learned about the authority of the Prophet in guiding the community's religious practices?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: What does this narration imply about the flexibility of prayer positions in certain circumstances?

hadith-eng: I observed with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) eight (rak'ahs) in combination, and seven rak'ahs in combination. I (one of the narrators) said: O Abd Sha'tha', I think that he (the Holy Prophet) had delayed the noon prayer and hastened the afternoon prayer, and he delayed the sunset prayer and hastened the 'Isha' prayer. He said: I also think so.
question: What are the possible reasons for delaying or hastening prayers in Islamic practice?

hadith-eng: A person said to Ibn 'Abbas (as he delayed the prayer): Prayer. He kept silence. He again said: Prayer. He again kept silence, and he again cried: Prayer. He again kept silence and said: May you be deprived of your mother, do you teach us about prayer? We used to combine two prayers during the life of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be learned from the interaction between Ibn 'Abbas and the person questioning him about prayer?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: How does the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) address deviations in prayer practices during his time?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) bought a camel from me. When he came back to Medina, he ordered me to come to the mosque and observed two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's actions upon returning to Medina after a purchase?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) routine prayers from his wife A'isha's account?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: What role does Abu Huraira play in the transmission of hadiths?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).
question: What is the importance of affirming belief in Allah and the revelations during prayer?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) during the night (i. e. Tahajjud prayer) She replied: He used to pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting in the night, and when he recited the Qur'an while standing, he would bow himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow from the sitting position.
question: How did the Prophet (ﷺ) transition between different positions during his night prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the prayer of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). She said: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would observe prayer (Nafl) in a standing position as well as in a sitting position, and when he commenced the prayer in a standing position, he bowed in this very position, and when he commenced the prayer in a sitting position, he bowed in this very position.
question: What flexibility is allowed in the performance of Nafl prayers according to the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray while sitting (when he grew old) and he recited in this position and when the recitation equal to thirty or forty verses was left, he would then stand up and recite (for this duration) in a standing position and then bowed himself and then prostrated himself and did the same in the second rak'ah.
question: How does the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of prayer reflect flexibility in worship for those with physical limitations?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha how the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did in the two rak'ahs as he (observed them) sitting. She said: He would recite (the Qur'an) in them, and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and then bowed.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of prayer from his method of performing two rak'ahs while seated?

hadith-eng: I said to 'A'isha and she made a mention of that (recorded above) about the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).
question: What can be learned about the reliability of hadith transmission from the interactions between companions?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Yahya al-A'raj with the same chain of transmitters.
question: What role do transmitters play in preserving the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: I accompanied Ibn 'Umar on the road to Mecca and he led us in two rak'ahs at the noon prayer, then he went forward and we too went along with him to a place where he alighted, and he sat and we sat along with him, and he cast a glance to the side where he said prayer and he saw people standing and asked: What are they doing? I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).
question: What does the hadith imply about the practice of offering additional prayers during travel?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. Allah, the Exalted, has said:" Verily there is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah."
question: What is the significance of observing the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in understanding Islamic practices?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said four rak'ahs in the noon prayer while at Medina, but he offered two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of varying prayer lengths in different circumstances?

hadith-eng: This hadith has been transmitted by Shu'ba with the same chain of narrators and it is narrated from Simt, and the name of Shurahbil has not been mentioned, and he said that he had gone to a place called Dumin, situated at a distance of eighteen miles from Hims.
question: Why might certain names be omitted in the narration of a hadith?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been transmitted by Anas, but no mention has been made of Pilgrimage.
question: Why might certain elements, such as Pilgrimage, be omitted in some narrations of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: I prayed behind the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Mina, and there was the greatest number of people, and they prayed two rak'ahs on the occasion of the Farewell Pilgrimage. (Muslim said: Haritha b. Wahb al-Khuza'i is the brother of 'Ubaidullah b. 'Umar son of Khattab from the side of his mother.)
question: What can be learned from the practice of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) regarding prayer during Hajj?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."
question: What instructions did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) give regarding prayer during inclement weather?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.
question: What role does the Mu'adhdhin play in communicating changes to prayer arrangements due to weather conditions?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this that Ibn 'Abbas ordered his Mu'adhdhin (to summon people to prayer and then make announcement to say prayer in their houses) on Friday which was a rainy day, has been transmitted by 'Abdullah b. Harith. Wuhaib, however, says that he did not hear it from him.
question: What is the significance of the role of a Mu'adhdhin in communicating changes in prayer arrangements?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practice of prayer during journeys from this narration?

hadith-eng: We met Anas b. Malik as he came to Syria at a place known as 'Ain-al-Tamar and saw him observing prayer on the back of his donkey with his face turned in that direction. (Hammam one of the narrators) pointed towards the left of Qibla, so I said to him: I find you observing prayer towards the side other than that of Qibla. Upon this he said: Had I not seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) doing like this, I would not have done so at all.
question: What can be learned from Anas b. Malik's adherence to the practices of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) in prayer?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What can be inferred about the timing of voluntary prayers in relation to the obligatory prayers from this incident?

hadith-eng: No one has ever narrated to me that he saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing the forenoon prayer, except Umm Hani. She, however, narrated that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) entered her house on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and prayed eight rak'ahs (adding): I never saw a shorter prayer than it except that he performed the bowing and prostration completely. But (one of the narrators) Ibn Bashshar in his narration made no mention of the word:" Never".
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from the account of Umm Hani?

hadith-eng: I had been asking about, as I was desirous to find one among people who should inform me, whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the forenoon prayer, but I found none to narrate that to me except Umm Hani, daughter of Abu Talib (the real sister of Hadrat 'Ali), who told me that on the day of the Conquest the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) came (to our house) after the dawn had (sufficiently) arisen. A cloth was brought and privacy was provided for him (the Holy Prophet). He took a bath and then stood up and observed eight rak'ahs. I do not know whether his Qiyam (standing posture) was longer, or bending or prostration or all of them were of equal duration. She (Umm Hani) further said: I never saw him saying this Nafl prayer prior to it or subsequently. (Al-Muradi narrated on the authority of Yunus that he made no mention of the words:" He informed me." )
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) prayer habits from Umm Hani's account?

hadith-eng: A hadith like this has been narrated by Abu Huraira by another chain of transmitters.
question: Why is it important to consider different chains of narrators when studying hadith literature?

hadith-eng: "Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us..." verse 136 from Surah Baqara, and in the second of the two: "I believe in Allah and I bear testimony that we are Muslims" (iii. 52).

hadith-eng: " Say: We believed in Allah and what was revealed to us" and that which is found in Surah Al-i-'lmran:" Come to that word (creed) which is common between you and us" (iii. 64).

hadith-eng: A house will be built in Paradise, for anyone who prays in a day and a night twelve rak'ahs; and she added: I have never abandoned (observing them) since I heard it from the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ). hadith-eng: He who observed twelve voluntary rak'ahs, a house will be built for him in Paradise.

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to pray while sitting (when he grew old) and he recited in this position and when the recitation equal to thirty or forty verses was left, he would then stand up and recite (for this duration) in a standing position and then bowed himself and then prostrated himself and did the same in the second rak'ah.
question: How can one incorporate flexibility in prayer positions while maintaining the essence of the prayer?

hadith-eng: I said to 'Umar b. al-Khattab, and the rest of the hadlth is the same.
question: What role does seeking clarification play in understanding religious practices?

hadith-eng: I fell ill and lbn 'Umar came to inquire after my health, and I asked him about the glorification of Allah (i. e. prayer) while travelling. Thereupon he said: I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey but I did not see him glorifying Him, and were I to glorify (Him). I would have completed the prayer. question: What is the significance of observing the practices of the Prophet Muhammad in understanding Islamic rituals?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said four rak'ahs in the noon prayer while at Medina, but he offered two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.

hadith-eng: I observed four rak'ahs in the noon prayer with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at Medina, and said two rak'ahs in the afternoon prayer at Dhu'l-Hulaifa.
question: What can be learned from the Prophet's practice of performing four rak'ahs in the noon prayer and two in the afternoon prayer?

hadith-eng: We went out from Medina to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he prayed two rak'ahs at each time of prayer till we returned to Medina. I said: For how long did he stay in Mecca? He said: (For) ten (days).
question: How long did the Prophet (ﷺ) stay in Mecca during this journey, and what does it imply about his travel practices?

hadith-eng: I heard Anas b. Malik say: We went out for Pilgrimage from Medina. The rest is the same.
question: How does the journey from Medina to perform pilgrimage reflect the practices of early Muslims?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said two rak'ahs at Mina, and Abu Bakr after him, and 'Umar after Abu Bakr, and 'Uthman at the beginning of his caliphate; then 'Uthman observed four rak'ahs, and when Ibn 'Umar prayed with the Imam, he said four rak'ahs, but when he observed prayer alone, he said two rak'ahs.
question: What was Ibn 'Umar's practice regarding the number of rak'ahs when praying with the Imam versus praying alone?

hadith-eng: I saw the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) praying (Nafl prayer) on a donkey's back while his face was turned towards Khaibar.
question: What can be inferred about the Prophet's (ﷺ) practices regarding prayer while on a journey from this narration?

hadith-eng: 'Abdullah b. 'Amir b. Rabi'a has reported on the authority of his father that he had seen the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observing Nafl player at night on a journey on the back of his ride in whichever direction it turned its face.
question: What does this narration imply about the importance of maintaining voluntary prayers during travel?

hadith-eng: The dawn prayer had commenced when the Messen- ger of Allah (ﷺ) saw a person observing prayer, whereas the Mu'adhdhin had pronounced the Iqama. Upon this he (the Holy Prophet) remarked: Do you say four (rak'ahs) of Fard in the dawn prayer?
question: What does this narration imply about the timing and structure of obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: The Apostle of Allah (ﷺ) owed me a debt; he paid me back and made an addition (of this). I entered the mosque and he (the Holy Prophet) said to me: Observe two rak'ahs of prayer.
question: What is the importance of offering prayer in the mosque according to Islamic tradition?

question: How does the Prophet's practice of prayer reflect on the permissibility of praying while sitting or standing?

hadith-eng: We went out from Medina to Mecca with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he prayed two rak'ahs at each time of prayer till we returned to Medina. I said: For how long did he stay in Mecca? He said: (For) ten (days).

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings, pray in your dwellings, and then said: When it was a cold night or it was raining in a journey the Messenger of Allah (may peace he upon him) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to announce: Pray in your dwellings.

hadith-eng: I entered the mosque, when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been sitting among people, and I also sat down among them. I said: Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and people sitting (around you and I, therefore, sat in your company). hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) happened to pass by a person who was busy in praying while the (Fard of the) dawn prayer had commenced. He said something to him, which we do not know what it was. When we turned back we surrounded him and said: What is it that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to you? He replied: He (the Holy Prophet) had said to me that he perceived as if one of them was about to observe four (rak'ahs) of the dawn prayer. Qa'nabi reported that 'Abdullah b. Malik b. Buhaina narrated it on the authority of his father. (Abu'l-Husain Muslim said): His assertion that he has narrated this hadith on the authority of his father is not correct.

I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Uthman and he made no addition to two rak'ahs, till Allah caused him to die, and Allah has said:" There is a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah" (al-Qur'an, xxxiii. 21).

I said: Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and people sitting (around you and I, therefore, sat in your company). hadith-eng: I went with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on an expedition and my camel delayed me and I was exhausted. He said: It is now that you have come. I said. Yes. He said: Leave your camel and enter (the mosque) and observe two rak'ahs. hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.

hadith-eng: I did not see the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) reciting (the Qur'an) in the night prayer in a sitting position, till he grew old and then he recited (it) in a sitting position, but when thirty or forty verses were left out of the Surah, he would then stand up, recite them and then bowed.

Upon this 'Abdullah said: Is there not a model pattern for you in the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)? hadith-eng: I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the day of the Conquest of Mecca and found him taking a bath, and Fatimah, his daughter, had provided him privacy with the help of a cloth. When he had completed the bath, he stood up and observed eight rak'ahs wrapped up in one cloth. When he turned back (after the prayer), I said to him: Messenger of Allah, the son of my mother 'Ali b. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. Umm Hani said: It was the forenoon (prayer).

I said: They are engaged in glorifying Allah, offering Sunnah prayer. He said: If I had done so I would have perfected my prayer; O my nephew! I accompanied the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on a journey, and he made no addittion to two rak'ahs, till Allah called him. I accompanied Abu Bakr and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. I accompanied 'Umar and he made no addition to two rak'ahs till Allah caused him to die. Abu Talib is going to kill a person, Fulan b. Hubaira whom I have given protection. Upon this the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: We too have given protection whom you have given protection, O Umm Hani. hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha how the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) did in the two rak'ahs as he (observed them) sitting. She said: He would recite (the Qur'an) in them, and when he intended to bow, he would stand up and then bowed.
question: How does the practice of sitting during prayer reflect on the flexibility of Islamic prayer rituals?

hadith-eng: I told 'Umar b. al-Khattab that Allah had said:" You may shorten the prayer only if you fear that those who are unbelievers may afflict you" (Qur'an, iv. 101), whereas the people are now safe. question: What was Umar b. al-Khattab's understanding of the conditions for shortening prayers, and how did the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) clarify it?

hadith-eng: When you have announced" I testify that there is no god but Allah; I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," do not say:" Come to the prayer," but make this announcement:" Say prayer in your houses." Jumu'a prayer is no doubt obligatory, but I do not like that I should (force you) to come out and walk in mud and slippery ground.
question: What is the significance of the flexibility in the call to prayer during challenging circumstances, as demonstrated by the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed the noon and afternoon prayers together, and the sunset and Isha' prayers together without being in a state of fear or in a state of journey.

hadith-eng: My Friend (ﷺ) instructed me in three (acts), and I would never abandon them as long as I live. (And these three things are): Three fasts during every month, the forenoon prayer, and this that I should not sleep till I have observed the Witr prayer.
question: Why is it important to perform the Witr prayer before sleeping, and what significance does it hold in daily worship?

question: Why might certain narrators be omitted in different versions of the same hadith?

hadith-eng: Pray in your dwellings; and then said: When it was a cold, rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to command the Mu'adhdhin to say" Pray in your dwellings."

hadith-eng: The prayer was prescribed as two rak'ahs, two rak'ahs both in journey and at the place of residence. The prayer while travelling remained as it was (originally prescribed), but an addition was made in the prayer (observed) at the place of residence.

hadith-eng: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said two rak'ahs at Mina, and Abu Bakr after him, and 'Umar after Abu Bakr, and 'Uthman at the beginning of his caliphate; then 'Uthman observed four rak'ahs, and when Ibn 'Umar prayed with the Imam, he said four rak'ahs, but when he observed prayer alone, he said two rak'ahs.
question: What does Ibn 'Umar's practice of praying differently with the Imam and alone indicate about individual and congregational prayer?

hadith-eng: I entered the mosque, when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) had been sitting among people, and I also sat down among them. question: Why might someone choose to sit immediately upon entering a mosque, and what guidance does the Prophet (ﷺ) provide in this situation?

hadith-eng: I aksed 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) used to observe the forenoon prayer. She said: No, except when he came back from a journey.
question: How did A'isha describe the Prophet's (ﷺ) routine concerning the forenoon prayer after returning from a journey?

hadith-eng: In the morning charity is due from every bone in the body of every one of you. Every utterance of Allah's glorification is an act of charity. Every utterance of praise of Him is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Oneness is an act of charity, every utterance of profession of His Greatness is an act of charity, enjoining good is an act of charity, forbidding what is distreputable is an act of charity, and two rak'ahs which one prays in the forenoon will suffice.
question: What is the significance of performing two rak'ahs in the forenoon according to Islamic tradition?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha about the Messenger of Allah's (ﷺ) voluntary prayers, and she replied: Before the noon prayer, he used to pray four rak'ahs in my house; then would go out and lead the people in prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. He would then lead the people in the sunset prayer; then come in and pray two rak'ahs. Then he would lead the people in the 'Isha' prayer, and enter my house and pray two rak'ahs. He would pray nine rak'ahs during the night, including Witr. At night he would pray for a long time standing and for a long time sitting, and when he recited the Holy Qur'an while standing, he would bow and prostrate himself from the standing position, and when he recited while sitting, he would bow and prostrate himself from the sitting position, and when it was dawn he would pray two rak'ahs.
question: What can be learned about the Prophet Muhammad's (ﷺ) dedication to prayer from his practice of praying both before and after leading the obligatory prayers?

hadith-eng: 'A'isha reported that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) would pray in the night for a long time, and when he prayed standing be bowed in a standing posture, and when he prayed sitting, he bowed in a sitting posture.
question: What can be inferred about the flexibility in prayer postures during night prayers?

hadith-eng: I asked 'A'isha whether the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) observed (Nafl) sitting. She said: Yes, when the people had made him old.

hadith-eng: Salim b. 'Abdullah (b. 'Umar) reported on the authority of his father that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) observed the prayer of a traveller, i. e. two rak'ahs in Mina, and other places; so did Abu Bakr and 'Umar, and 'Uthman too observed two rak'ahs at the beginning of his caliphate, but he then completed four.
